4427833/4348547/4435530.title: Fianna Traditions
4427833/4348547/4435530.text: There is really only one connection, if it is one, with the Fianna in this locality.  Tobar Caoilte is supposed to be named after one of the Fianna.  It is in the Balla parish in the townland of Ballyclougher.  It keeps on summer and winter and does not dry even when other wells in the locality run dry.  The other Fianna reference is to a large stone which is in the curate's garden as is said to have been thrown from a neighbouring hill.  These are the only references to the Fianna I could find in Balla parish.

4428091/4377450/4435728.title: Na Fathaigh
4428091/4377450/4435728.text: Uair amháin bhí Fionn MacCumhail ina gcomhnuidhe i Móin na Tarbh. Aon lá amháin do chonnaic sé an Gchiadchoigh Mór ag teacht. Dubhairt an bhean leo dul isteach ar an cliabháin. Do chuaidh sé isteach agus cuir sí an eadaige inairde air. Do tháinigh an Gchiadcoigh isteach. "Tabhair don an tarbh breágh mór" arsa sé. "Níl na fir istigh mar tá siad ag fiadhiac" arsan bhean "ní tabharfaidh mise an tarbh dó".  "Tóg mise é" arsan gchiadcoigh agus nuair a tháinigh na fir, dubhairt tú gurb é an gchiadcoig Mór a thógaig é" arsan fear. Do cuaig an Gciadcoig tríd na páirceanna agus thóg sé tarbh. Nuair a bhí sé ag teacht go dtí an crosaire leis an tarbh, bhí Fionn Mac Cumhail ag an gcrosaire. Dubhairt Fionn an thóg tú an tarbh agus dubhairt an Gciadciog go dtógadh é. Annsan do rug Fionn ar adhairc an tairbh agus do rug an Gciadciog ar an eirbheall agus thosnuig ag strachadh. Níor stad gur strach an tarbh ina dhá leath.

4428091/4377465/4435735.title: Fathach
4428091/4377465/4435735.text:
Ba é Fionn Mac Cumhail an fatach dob fhearr a bhí in Éireann le na linn. Rith sé ó Recormac le'n a ainm agus a namhaid in a dhiaidh nó go shrois sé innse ar port Aba Móire timcheall trí mhíle ar thiar do'n mBaile Dubh. Thug sé fé an Aba Mhór agus tháinigh sé trasna na h-abha in aon léim amháin agus glaodhann siad Innse an Léime ar an áit ó shoin. Annsin thriall sé ar an mBaileinn agus bhí comhnuidhe a mbun Gleann Shast ar feadh tamaill maith. Leastíar do'n corál cloc bhí an tigh aige. Lá aithre tháinigh gaisceac Innse na Clompa chun troid leis. Nuair a chonnaic na banaltra ag teacht é dúirt sí le Fionn luighe sa cliabhain agus go gcluideác sí ann é agus do dhein sé agus niarbh fada gur bhuail an gaisceac an doras isteach. "Tá an gaoth sa doras agat a bhean mhaith" ar seisean. "Tá" arsa sí sin "ach dá mbeadh na fearaibh sa bhaile ionpódais an tigh timcheall". Tighthe adhmad a bhíodh aca an uair úd agus níor dhein an gaisceach ach a gualainn do chur le cúinne an tigh agus é iompód timcheall. "Cábhfuil na fearaibh?" ar sé sin. "Tá siad imtighthe ó bhaile ag féadach go dtí an Gleann Síocáin.
(continues on next page)

4427872/4353060/4437702.text: 438Old StoriesFionn Mac Cual was fighting and he won the fightWhen the battle was over he went into his tent an started praying. He was nothing in his tent till a soldier came in, drew his sword and killed him.Thomas McEveney,Newbrook,Ballyglass,Co. MayoGot from, John Heaney,Newbrook,TaugheenClaremorrisAge 72 years.

4427839/4349107/4439928.title: An Old Story
4427839/4349107/4439928.text:
Long ago there was a giant in Norway called Monover and there was another giant in Ireland called Finn. Monover had been listening to stories about Finn's greatness for a long time, so at length he set out for Ireland to beat Finn. Monover had beaten every giant in the world. He sent Finn word that he was coming and when Finn got this news he did not know what to do. He told his wife the trouble he was in.She at once thought up a trick. There was a cradle in the house, but it must have been a big one. She put Finn in the cradle. "Now," said she, "I'll say that you're not at home". Soon Monover came.
(continues on next page)

4428101/4378295/4443984.title: Story
4428101/4378295/4443984.text:
When St. Carthage was crossing the Ferry - when entering Lismore first - he met the two daughters of the Chieftain. To one of them he offered an apple for which she reached out her left hand. A second time he offered it and again, she put forward the left hand. She was unable to use her right hand as she and her sister were joined together.The third time he told her to put out the right hand. This she did, proving he at once had worked a miracle. Given bySeán DooleyChristina Brother SchoolsPortlaoighis



Finn Mac Cumhaill and his wife lived at Baile Fhinn.A Scottish giant, hearing of Finn's prowess, came over to have a Comhraic Aonair. Before he reached the house, Finn's wife saw him.
(continues on next page)

4428104/4378235/4444723.title: Shéan Castle
4428104/4378235/4444723.text: Another of these old castles may be seen about a quarter of a mile from a well called Tobar Mo Choda.In the vicinity of this castle some sixty years ago were found pieces of gold supposed to be remnants of armour worn by Normans in battles fought here.Tradition has it that Fionn Mac Cumhail with his army was in flight from West Cork from his enemies, escaping to Youghal and Camphire.He carried his mother on his back. Arriving at a hill south of this castle called Drom Fhinghín, he, looking over his shoulder, found he had but his mother's feet; the mother's body was divided with the force of strength used by Fionn in his flight. Hence the name Drom-Finghín. This hill stretches from West Cork to the junction of the River Blackwater and Bride at Camphire.

4450396/4376068/4450425.title: An Chaoi a bhFuair Monomhar Bás
4450396/4376068/4450425.text:
Rígh do b'eadh Monomhar. Tháinig sé ó'n Spáinn. Sé an fáth ar tháinig sé, bhí Righ eile i n-Éirinn d'ár b'ainm Finn. Chuala Monomhar go leór sgéalta faoi Fhinn agus níor thaithnigh sé leis chor ar bith mar bhí sé ag ceapadh go raibh Finn níos fearr ná é fhéin.Ní raibh Righ i n-Éirinn nach raibh buailte ag Monomhar acht Finn, agus ní bheadh sé sásta go ndéanfadh Sé an rudh céadhna le Finn.Lá amháin dubhairt sé leis fhéin nach stopfadh sé go rachfadh sé go dtí Finn. Annsin chuir sé sgéala ag Finn go raibh sé le theacht.Nuair a chuala Finn é seo ní raibh fhios aighe sa domhan céardh a dhéanfadh sé. D'innis sé gun bhean fhaoi an triobhlóid ina raibh sé ann. Chuimhnigh sise ar chleas. Bhí clíabhán sa teach aca.Caithfidh sé gur ceann mór a bhí ann!Chuir sí Finn isteach sa gclíabhán.Anois adeir sí nuair a thiocfas
(continues on next page)

4450396/4376082/4450431.title: Scéal - An Bás
4450396/4376082/4450431.text:
Is hait an mac é an bás. Tá sé in-an reitheadh an domhain a throid.Bhí Goll, Oscar agus Fionn ag siubhal lá gur tháinic an oidhche othra casadh isteach i dteach íad.Bí bean bhreagh óg istigh agus sean-fhear beag in-a shuidhe ar an mbac.Bhí bríste geár air agus stocaí fada bróga ísle agus casóg sgiortach agus hata árd.Bhí reithe cengailte i gceann an tighe.Núair a bhí síad tamall istigh thug sí béile dóibh, nuair a bhí síad ag ithe sgaoil an reithe agus thosuigh sé ag ithe ag an mbord leó.Dubhairt sí lé duine aca é
(continues on next page)

4427926/4358165/4454578.title: Story of the Fianna
4427926/4358165/4454578.text: One day Oisín was sitting on a river bank by himself when a fish swan up to him and said "You shall one day go to a lovely country in the West" but Oisín would not believe him and the fish swam away and said "Remember my words to thee Oisín". When Oisín went to the camp of the fianna he told what he had seen and heard and they all laughed at it and never thought any more until he did go to the country in the West and then he thought of what the fish told him and he wished to go back to Ireland so he did go back and when (when) he fell of the horse he happened to fall beside a pool of water where hw saw the same fish again who said "It is I who brought the misfortune on you for not believing me if you had believed me you would be a young man today in the country in the West". Oisín said Oisín "what a fool I was".  "You are late now for I am the salmon of knowledge and he went away and Oisín never saw him again.

4428070/4374966/4457043.title: How Finn Won His Wife
4428070/4374966/4457043.text:
When Finn was out hunting one day he came to a wide chasm between two rocks. It was so deep that the river running below could not be heard over the bank above. One one side stood a lovely lady and ten hand-maidens around her. She wore a lovely cloak and a brooch of pure gold on her breast, and on her arms were many gold bracelets. On the other side were several men, and in their midst stood a prince wearing a tunic of green and a brooch of silver. As Fionn gazed he saw the prince go back from the chasm, then turning swiftly the prince ran hot - foot to the chasm but failed to leap it. Fionn asked the meaning of all this. He was told that the prince wished to marry the lady, but that she
(continues on next page)

4428070/4374983/4457074.title: Dermot and Grania
4428070/4374983/4457074.text:
Once Finn was going to get married to Grania, daughter of the High-King of Ireland. The High King had a feast the night before the wedding. Finn and all the Fianna were present. Grania told her maid to bring her some wine and she did. She gave some of the wine to Finn and all the Fianna except Diarmuid and Duibhas. They all went to sleep, except Dairmuid, and Grania asked him to marry her. He agreed, and they rode away in the King's chariot till they came to Sligo where they met a man named Modan. Modan and they rode on till they came to Curltens where Modan built a cave with an iron door and iron winde. They waited there a small while; Dermot and Grania slept
(continues on next page)

4428273/4390563/4457750.title: A Legend of Finn Mc Cool
4428273/4390563/4457750.text:
In the olden days, when most of the country, even the boglands, was under wood, Finn Mc Cool  and his companions made periodic hunting incursions into Donegal, especially south Donegal. It is said that Finn knew every inch of territory from Lough Derg (of the pilgrimage) to Glencolumkille. It is also said that he knew from the taste of the venison in what particular wood or district in this region the deer had been killed. Finn and his companions went to Glencolmcille and Teelin on a hunting expedition, and incidentally, to seek and select recruits for the Fianna. They killed many deer on this expedition. From there they journeyed to the Glenties district where they remained for a month. Then they set their course toward the south east for the woodlands around Lough Derg. In Barnes Gap a fine deer was sighted and hounds and men gave eager chase. The hills echoed for a whole day to the clan own and shouting of the Fianna and the laying of the Rounds. The latter, baffled at every turn, hid, in their despair, ‘the rocks that yelled again’ the chase was
(continues on next page)

Bhí sin ann agus is fada ó bhí. Nuair a mhar na Fianna i n-Éirinn bhíodh na n-aidhcheanntar an fhuar san gheimhreadh. Oidche amháin nuair a bhí na fianna uilig na cuighe chaolaidh cead an doras agus d'iarr ar an duine a cheaic isteach le sin shiubhail an t-seanbhean a ba ghraice a chonnaie sí ariamh isteach. D'feafraigh sé díthe caide bhí ag cur bhuadharia ourgh. Dusbharr sise go rabh dídean na h-rdhce a d'ith orti ash dubhairt. Fionn noch dtabhairfeadh seisean dideán ar bith díre agus thiantuigh sé anach agus thúsaigh sí a chaorneadh ainsin agus grionn cupla bom aice eile thainig sí ar ais agus bhuail ag doras Oisín. Chuaidh Oisín fhadh leis an doras agus d'iarr a rthí a theach isteach. Thainig an t-seanbhean isteach agus nuair a chonnaire Oisín an cineál mná a bhí cinnte d'fheafraigh sé dithe go feargach caide. Bhí a dith arthe. Dubhairg sí go rabh dídean na h-ordche a digh orthu agus ag dubhairg Oisín noi rabh dídeán ar bith le fághail aice agus thionntaigh ama í. I gcionn tamaill thainig sí arais agus bhuail ag doras dhiarmade.

4428228/4387511/4458583.title: A Few Sidelights on Patrick H. Pearse as I Saw him
4428228/4387511/4458583.text:
Jan 4th 1938A Few side-lights on Patrick H. Pearse as I saw him.My first sight of P.H.Pearse was in the autumn of 1911. When Pearse, full of the success of his school in Cullenswood House Ranelagh (Rathmines) took over the large stone mansion and grounds called the Hermitage - now for all time to be known as "St Endas" he was full of hope. Two of his three goals in life  were well within measurable distance of full atainment. The world now knows his last goal and its attainment has added another chapter to irish history.When Pearse came to Rathfarnham he came with the full knowledge and trust and encouragement of his mother whom he consulted in everything- his brother William who had just then completed his studies in the Life Class for drawingin conjunction with his work in sculpture also came with him.I first had words with Pearse-Gaedhilg of course. It was a wet evening in late
(continues on next page)

4428236/4387492/4458999.title: The Three Rocks
4428236/4387492/4458999.text:
It is said that Finn Mac Cool once had a  competition in stone throwing with a Scotch giant at Wexford. The Giant threw them to the Scalp and Finn to the Two Rock and Three Rocks.Finally he threw a good big one to Howth and the Giant gave in, This is of course a fairy story



On the north-western side of the Three Rocks is a hole or cave in Fulhan's glen.It was said that when flogging was in the army a soldier to avoid it came out there and died. His body was found and since then it has that name. This cave was also used as a dump and hiding place after 1916.

4428274/4390751/4459074.title: Old Irish Tales
4428274/4390751/4459074.text: In my district there are stories of the men of Fionn Mac bumhall. These men are called the Fionna. There are stones of immense size supposed to be thrown by Fionn. However these stones are very plentiful all over the countryside some in rivers others in glens and on hills. There are Danish forts on a lot of hills. No one ever destroys these forts. There are small trees growing in rocky ground these are fairy trees.

4428136/4381115/4459720.title: Stories and Songs
4428136/4381115/4459720.text:
(continued from previous page)
Many stories are told about fairies who lived long ago. Most of those are told about a ghost by the name of Petticoat Loose. The following is one about her.Long ago a man named O'Brien from The Nire was returning from Clonmel. It was night. He had a horse and cart and a big load. It was very dark and cold. About two miles outside he overtook a woman who begged of him to give her a drive and so he did. Immediately she sat up the horse was unable to pull the load. She told the man that if it would not pull it, it would be dead next morning. The man left it at a house nearby. When he came next morning the horse was dead.

Thinking the dog would never come back, Fionn sent Oscar after him. Running a little, Oscar made a ferocious leap through the air and landed on top of Deirick, having gone through the air for a distance of about nine miles. He seized the dog and brought it safely to Fionn.

4462381/4415986/4463415.title: Tales of The Fianna
4462381/4415986/4463415.text:
Fionn Mac Cumhal had arrived at Tar on the night before Samhain when the feast was just beginning. He was dressed in skins of wild animals and he looked so proud and noble that the guards allowed him to pass in. He walked in to the room and stood before the King.No one spoke, but everybody in the hall was watching Fionn. "What is your name"? asked the King. "I am Fionn, the son of Cumhail". You are the son of a friend," said the King kindly, and he asked the attendents to find a seat for Fionn. When the feast was over, the King rose and spoke. He reminded them that an Enchanter always
(continues on next page)

4427953/4360782/4464799.title: Columcille and his Mother's Sickness
4427953/4360782/4464799.text:
Once time Columcille's mother was very sick and every morning he used to ask her how she was. The first few mornings she said she was bad and he used to say "May you be worse tomorrow" Anyway on the third day she said "I am good thank God" and he said "May you be better". She was better and kept getting better until she was completely better. The reason he said "May you be worse" was because she did not show confidence in God.

4427964/4361627/4465573.title: (no title)
4427964/4361627/4465573.text: Do réir béal oideas na ndaoine bhí Fionn ag seilg ar Néifin Mhór lá amháin. Is dócha go raibh Bran agus Sceolán leis ach nílmuid cinnte. Deirtear gur tháinig sé cómh fada lé Sraithín agus ar a bhealach tríd an baile sin dó   bhí air a dhul thar claidhe agus bhí carraig mór fairsing ar an sgonnsa sin. Deirtear gur fathach a chur an cloch 'san rioch sin.  Tháingh Fionn agus ag dul thar an cloch dhó bhúaíl a chóta é agus thuit an cloch ó'n gclaidhe agus ó'n lá sin go dtí an lá atá indú ann níor chorruigh aon duine é. Tá an cloch céadna lé feiceál anois. Bheul! níor chuir an méid sin imnidhe ar Fionn  chúaidh sé ar aghaidh ar nós na gaoithe ach ar thuitim na h-oidhce  bhí sé sáruighthe. D'féach sé uaidh; chonnaich sé carraig mór ar chnochán agus súid leis go dtí é.Do shuidh sé síos air ach is amhlaidh a rinne sé cathoir de. Tá an rían sin lé feicheál anois agus tugtar Suidhe Finn air,  agus 'sé an t-ainm atá ar an gceanntar thart timcheall ná Suidhe Finn.

4428335/4396891/4466038.title: A Fenian Tale
4428335/4396891/4466038.text:
This is an old Fenian tale telling how Glen Finn, Lough Finn and Lough Muck derived their names.Once upon a time there dwelt an old widower in a little village now known as Glen Finn. This man was poor and had but two children, a son whose name was Feargown and a daughter whose name was Finn. He loved his two children dearly and was greatly attached to both.One day a few Fenians with their noble leader Fionn came to the hut seeking food. The old man replied, saying he was poor and had little food in his house, but if the wished to go out and kill any animal they so desired, they would be welcome to cook it at his hearth and partake of the meal at his table. The did so, bringing with them the widower's son to show them where some wild animals were. They soon came in sight of a wild boar. The Fenians being afraid to attack such a furious animal left the task in the hands of Feargown. He, brave, strong and ventursome killed the boar in less than no time. The fenians admiring his bravery very much, asked him to join them. Natuarly enough the old man did not want to part with his only son, but after further persuasion from the Fenians he gave him consent to go on conditions that he would return at the end of seven years. The son did so and with the Fenians he wroght great bravery. At the end of which time he went up to his
(continues on next page)

4427968/4362446/4466127.title: Old Irish Tales
4427968/4362446/4466127.text: There is a place in my district called Grainne's bed.  Some people call it Grainne's Rock and others call it leabaidh Grainne.  This rock is on a hill called Maol which is in Callow. Once upon a time Fionn wanted Grainne to marry him.  But Grainne wanted to marry Diarmuid Ó Duibne who was the nicest looking boy of the Fianna.Fionn was nearly sixty years when he was about to marry Grainne.  Grainne and Diarmuid came to Connacht and Fionn came after them in search of Grainne.Grainne slept on this rock while coming through Callow.  This rock is about two feet wide,  It is in between two other rocks which are about four yards high.

4428251/4388500/4466204.title: Sheegus Hill
4428251/4388500/4466204.text: Sheegus Hill is situated about one mile and a half from Ballyshannon. It is a large hill now covered with brambles and weeds. It is said that Finn Mae Cumhall was walking along this district he got tried. He sat down on a little mound on Sheegus Hill. After a little while he got [sic] and saw he had bruised down the bank. The old people say it was the weight of Finn Mac Cumhall that made this hollow.
4428251/4388500/4466204.school_info: School: St Joseph's, Béal Átha Seanaigh

4428114/4379486/4467124.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4428114/4379486/4467124.text:
Bhí Fionn Mac Cumhal aon oíche amháin istig in tig áirthe agus chonaic sé braitlín deas isteach sa leaba agus bhí an-dhúil aige ann.D'imigh sé leis amach as an tigh. Bhí gabhar aige sa mbaile agus dhein sé an gabhar a mharbhughadh agus chuir sé an chroiceann air. Chuaidh sé go dtí an tig arís agus d'imigh sé síos an seimné agus bhí muintir an tighe ina chodladh. Thosnaigh sé ag déanamh glór agus d'éirigh muintir an tighe. Ghuid Finn isteach sa seomra agus ghuid sé an braitlín.



Bhí fear ann fadó gus bhí sé de bheús aige dul go dtí an baile mór gach lá. An oíche seo níor tháinigh sé abhaile. D'fhan sé san baile mór i dtigh a aintín.Bhí a aintín an-aosta agus bhí sí as a mheabhair agus gach aon rud a bhíodh aici thug sí don bhfear é an oíche seo. Thug sí dó an t-aon píosa amháin císte a bhí aici agus fuair sí bás leis an ocras.Tháinigh fear bocht go dtí an tórramh agus sé an rud a dúirt sé ná "Tabhair-se
(continues on next page)
4428114/4379486/4467124.school_info: School: Maol an Chóirne, An Rinn

4427975/4363126/4467600.title: Suí Finn
4427975/4363126/4467600.text: On the left hand side quite near to the main road leading from Bonniconlon to the Gap  is a small round hill covered with heather and moss which is known as Suidh-Finn.It is said that this mound was one of Fionn's resting-places.Beside this is a village which is called "Drom-Suid-Finn" which has got his name from this hill

4427983/4363793/4469030.title: Diarmuid agus Gráinne
4427983/4363793/4469030.text:
Diarmuid agus GráinneSgatamh inéis Fionn Mac Cumhail pósadh fuair a bean bas. Ba mhaith leis an dara bean a pósad agus chuir sé teachtaire go dti teach Gráinne chun Gráinne a fhághail mar mnaoiNuair a chuaidh an teachtaire go dtí Gráinne dubhairt sí leis go raibh Fionn sáthach sean le bheith ina hathair di ach ar deireadh dubairt sí go ngabfadh sí go dti Fionn leis an teachtaire agus cuaidh.San oidhche nuair a bhí Fionn, Gol Mac Móirne, Diarmuid Ó Duibhne agus a lán eile do na Fianna ag suidhe isteach ag an bhfleadh roimh an pósadh. d’fiafruigh Gráinne cérbh iad na daoine a bhí ag an mbord. Dinnsigheadh dhi, agus ar an nóiméad sin thuit sí i ngrádh le Diarmuid. Ní raibh fios ag Gráinne ceard a dhéanfadh sí chun Diarmuid a thabhairt lei. Annsin thug sí deoch d’en cuid eile do na Fianna ach Diarmuid.Thuit codladh ar na Fianna eile agus nuair bhí siad ina gcodhladh d’iarr Gráinne ar Diarmuid a pósadh. Ní raibh Diarmuid sásta ealódh óna maighistir ach ara deire dimigh an bheirt agus pósadh iad.Nuair a dúisigh an chuid eile do na Fianna bhí brón agus mi shástacht orra agus lean siad Diarmuid agus Gráinne. Níor éirigh leo Diarmuid a ghabail choidhche agus ar deireadh thug Fionn maiteamhnas dó.Bhí siad mór le chéile ina diaid sin go dtí an lá
(continues on next page)

4428051/4372427/4469196.title: Little One Eye and Little Two Eye
4428051/4372427/4469196.text:
(continued from previous page)
very minute they did the one with the three eyes, one flew out of her head and went into the one with the one eye, and each of them could see with two eyes then and they went home and lived happy ever after.



This was not an Irish giant. He came from Norway or Sweden, and why he came was this. There was in those days a famous giant in Ireland called Fionn. Monover had been listening to stories about Finn's greatness for a long time so at length  he set out for Ireland till he should see for himself.  There was no other Giant he heard of in any other country that he had not beaten except Finn.  So he wanted to beat him too.  When Finn heard this he did not know what to do. He told his wife the trouble he was in . She at once thought of a trick. There was a cradle in the house and she put Finn into the cradle
(continues on next page)

4428011/4368052/4470925.title: Na Fianna i gCill Ghaobhair
4428011/4368052/4470925.text:
San allóid nuair a bhí na Fíanna í n-Éirinn agus Finn mar taoiseach ortha d'éirigh achrainn idir Finn agus ceann dhe na laochraí darbh ainm Díarmuid.Bhí súil ag Finn go bpósfeadh, Gráinne, é, acht bhí grádh mór ag Gráinne le Díarmuid, agus pósadh Díarmuid léithí.Bhí fearg mór ar Fhinn nuair a chuala sé fé’n bpósadh agus fuair sé eólas go raibh Diarmuid ’san Iarthar.Núair a bhí síad a theacadh, tháinig Díarmuid go paróiste Cille Gaobhair agus leig é féin, agus Gráinne a bhí in a éidigh leis, a sgíth í “Leabaidh Díarmuda” san paróiste seo.Tháinig Finn in a ndhiadh agus cuir a laochra fútha in “Áit na bhFíann” atá ’san paróiste seo freisin.D’éirigh achrainn éadtorra agus marbhadh
(continues on next page)

4428020/4368661/4474258.title: Composition - Old Irish Tales
4428020/4368661/4474258.text: The Fianna were of a noble race and Fionn Mac Cool was their leader. The Fianna were great hunters and they lived mostly on the wild animals which they killed.Fionn and his followers used to make huts.  They got rushes to form their beds.  Fionn Mac Cool had all sorts of dogs for killing wild animals.Oasian went to Fir-Na-Nog with Niamh of the golden hair.  He met this woman one day when he was hunting.  There is a place called "Folach Fiadh" in this district.  It is supposed to have been named after the Fianna.King Connor Mac Nessa is also said to have visited this district with a band of knights.

4428021/4368748/4474366.title: (no title)
4428021/4368748/4474366.text:
One winter's night as Finn was sitting in his tent, he heard a whistle coming across the hill side.  It seemed to come nearer and nearer every moment.  It was not long until he heard the knocking at the door; when he opened it a young girl walked in with a basket in her hand.  She left it in side and would not wait to speak.  When she went Finn looked in the basket and found two pups.  This is how Finn got his two famous dogs first.



Long ago a giant invited a man to a feast. The giant had a cow killed and he said to the man "if he did not eat half the cow he would kill him". The giant went out for a can of water then. The man then saw a bag in the end of the house. He took it and put it under his coat. Then he used to throw the meat into it,
(continues on next page)

4428298/4392868/4475996.title: The Local Fairs
4428298/4392868/4475996.text:
The local fairs are held in the town of Dunkineely. Fairs were not always held in towns. Buyers often transact their business at farmers houses. This custom is not still carried on in our district. In some places fairs were held which have since been discontinued. Fairs were discontinued because no person brought cattle there. There are no local traditions of fairs being held in [cemetries]? cemeteries in our neighbourhood. There is a special square for the cattle called the market square.Toll is not paid on the cattle sold. When an animal is sold money is given back, usually sixpence to every pound. It is called luck penny. The men show their agreement by striking their hands and spitting on the ground. The animals are marked in many ways, by clipping a piece of hair from the animals side [siccors]? scissors, other are marked with a paint called keel, and others are marked with ribbons tied to their tails. The halter is retained if  the animal is not walking. In this part of the country the halter is not often used. The greatest fairs of the year are the May fair and the Harvest fair. In some parts of Ireland
(continues on next page)

4428298/4392851/4476085.title: Food in Olden Times
4428298/4392851/4476085.text:
(continued from previous page)
It wasn't usual for people to eat late at night. Different kinds of food were used to suit the different seasons.For instance, they used fish during Lent and all Fridays of the year. On Halloween they used to make Boxty bread. This bread was made from potatoes and flour. First they used to take the skins off the potatoes, then they used to grate them on a tin, covered with holes. This tin was called a grater. Afterwards they used to stew the water out of them with a cloth, and mix together with some flour. Then the mixture was flattened out in a circular shape and put on to fry on a pan.In olden times Christmas was a great time of feasting. They used to kill and eat geese, turkeys, hares, rabbits and (all) sometimes goats. Tea was used for the first time about forty years ago. Bowls and pandies were used most commonly before cups came into vogue.



Long ago when Fionn Mc Cool and his companions were hunting the wild deer in Connacht they came to a little house which was built under the shadow of a high cliff. Being tired and hungry they thought they would get something to eat in it. Upon knocking at the door it was opened by an old woman who inquired what they wanted. Upon learning that they were hungry and thirsty she invited them inside and set a fine meal before them. When they had eaten and drunk their fill they returned out again. Great was their surprise to find another group of warriors sitting on the green outside the house. Fionn recognised their leader as his old
(continues on next page)

4428299/4392866/4476101.title: Laoi na Mná Móire
4428299/4392866/4476101.text:
A Oisín is binn liom do bhealAgus is annsacht don sgeal d’fhaghail uaitAr chrodhacht Oscar laochrach threunBheireadh as gach céim atha buaidhLá da rabh Oisín, Fionn, Feargail agus File Mhac FéileOsgar Fuilteach, Diarmud Donn, Conan Maol agus caogad eile de’n fhéin‘Sar d-triall ann seilge maidin ceo go Gleann an Smóil‘Sar ngadhar go daighearghaDar an (ámh sin ort a chléirigh agus ní gó (lie)Budh mhór ar mbród ar luathas ar gconAr saidhe ar thulaigh dúinn ó’s cionn gliuneBudh aoibhinn crainn duilluir a’ fhásCunlaith suaircais ag ceileabhar go grinn‘As ba bhinne linne a bhfuaim san áillLeig gach aon dinn de’n fhianAr ngadhar béil bhinne luath fa’n ghleannDo leig Fionn dhá ghadhar dheug‘S budh bhinne na tcuda a ngluinGhluaiseas leobhtha an eilit mhaolBudh ghile taobh na sneachta ar chrannBhidh an taobh eile ar dhath an ghuailA’s budh luathmhara í nó seabhach ar choillLeig gach aon dinn cú da hiall
(continues on next page)

4428035/4370591/4476242.title: Oisín
4428035/4370591/4476242.text:
Oisin was in Keerlan and his grave known as "Dún Dragon" is to be seen. One day he was brought threshing and he made a flail of hazel rods twisted and the first blow went half way through the stack. He got for dinner _ a quarter of beef, a mioscan of butter and a bannog of bread. He was blind at the time. He was asked what he thought of the dinner. He said "Gheobhainn ceathramha loin duibh chomh mór le do cheathramha MáirtGheobhainn caora caorthain chomh mór le do mhioscánGheobhainn duilleog eidhinn chomh mór le do srubhán To get the quarter of the blackbird he went out with his fidcóg and an apple in the end  of it. He blew it and the birds collected. At last a huge blackbird came over the sea. St. Patrick
(continues on next page)

4428027/4369742/4476352.title: Bás Ghol Mac Mórna
4428027/4369742/4476352.text: I n-éis catha tír an Áir (agus ní gan adhbhar a tugadh an t-ainm) nuair a bhí na Fianna buailte ag fluaighte an Áird Ríogh nó raibh aoinne beo acht Gol Mac Mórna, Bhí se an - luthcaughthe. Tharraing  sé abhaile é féin le bás d'fagháil. Dubhairt a bhean chéile leis go blianfadh sí bainne caoch ar a chuid  luthaí agus go leigheasóchadh sé iad. "Comhairle mná ó dheas nó ó thuaidh ní iarrfaidh nó  ní dhéanfidh ar seisean". Chuaidh se síos go dtí an fhairrge ag Cruimlic. D'fhan sé annsin gur shaith sé. Annsin chuaidh sé amach agus shuidh sé ar charraig go dtáinig an fhairrge ar ais agus báitheadh é
4428027/4369742/4476352.school_info: School: Baile an Chaisil C., Clochar na Trócaire

4427977/4363478/4476680.title: The Mountain Uaigh
4427977/4363478/4476680.text: About one mile north of Gleann Fraoigh, in the townland of Carrowleagh, in a mountainous district stands a mountain Uaigh or cave.It is now almost  covered by gorse and tall bulbrushes and waving ceannabhains surround the uaigh on all sides.This ancient cave is about 15 or 20 yards in length, 6 feet in depth, and 2 1/2 yards in width.It has a flagged floor, walls built of large flags and stones and a narrow doorway leads into it over which rest two huge flags.It is very difficult to find as it is in the heart of the mountains, surrounded by hundreds of acres of heather.It is said that Fionn and his Fianna chased a wild boar from the plains of Kildare until, after three days, it was killed by Bran, Fionn's famous hound, at the mouth of this uaigh.It is said, that in every great crisis in Ireland's history, the boar appears at the mouth of the Uaigh.
4427977/4363478/4476680.school_info: School: Ceathrú na gCloch, Gleann Fraoigh

4428303/4392906/4477435.title: Scéal fá Chró na Roda - Leabaidh Dhiarmada agus Ghráinne
4428303/4392906/4477435.text: Leabaidh Dhiarmuda agus Gráinne.Nuair a bhí Fionn indhiaidh Dhiarmuda agus Grainne bhí siad ar chnoc Cró-na-Nád aon uair amháin. Bhí cailleach ag Fhionn agus innseochadh sí do gach lá cá h-áit a rabh siad. Bhí Diarmuid cliste go leór duithse fosna no bhéarradh sé mála gainimh leis suas go dtí an chnoc agus chuirfeadh se isteach ins an uaimh é. Annsin sheasóchadh siad air agus nuair a thiocfadh Fionn ag amharc fa na gcoinne ní thiocfadh leis iad a fhághail ar an tráigh agus b’éigean do imtheacht. Mar an gcéadna bhéarfadh se ualach fraoich leis síos go dtí an tráigh agus sheasóchadh siad air annsin. Nuair a innseochadh an chailleach do Fhionn go rabh siad ar an fhraoch ní thiocfadh leis iad a fhághail annsin ach oiread agus mar sin de níor beireadh ortha.

4428303/4392935/4477606.title: Fathach
4428303/4392935/4477606.text:
Deirtear gur Fionn Mac Cumail rí na bfhatach. Am amháin bhí Fionn indiaidh an fhataigh as Albain, agus bhí Fionn ag fághail an bhuadha. Thóg  Fionn slamán creafoíge agus chaith sé na dhiaidh é. Thuit sé ag sáile an fhathaigh, agus sgairtear Oileán Mhanain ar an áir go fóill. Fósta sgairtear loch n-Éachach ar an pholl a d’fhág Fionn na dhiaidh.Annsin tháinig Fionn anall, agus chaith sé cloch mór – Thuit an cloch shuas ar an cnoc s’againne agus bheirtear cloch stucáin air.Tháinig sé fhéin anall annsin, agus shiud sé i gcathaoir mhóir ar an Choillin. Sgairtear cathaoir Fhinn ar an áit go fóill.



Long ago the people always played Caman. The strand was the play-field. They would start playing on Christmas day and then they would play until the end of Winter.They had sticks with turned heads on them for Camans, and what they played with was called a Bul, which was made from a round hazel or briar root. The field was the whole length
(continues on next page)

4428265/4389724/4477974.title: Old Irish Tales
4428265/4389724/4477974.text: The only local tradition about the Fianna is that a stone was supposed to be thrown by Fionn Mac Cool from the mountain of Turaw on the southern shore of Lough Erne to the townland of Carrickrory The stone is still to be seen and is called Fionn’s Fingerstone

4428308/4393817/4478081.title: Seanscéal
4428308/4393817/4478081.text:
Seo sgeal a bhaineás le Conan Maoil nuair a bhí sé ag silg thart fan cheanntair seo. Aon uair amháin bhí na Fianna agus Fionn Mac Cumhaill ag seilg in an pharóiste seo. Bhí siad ina comhnuidhe ag Mullan an Tighe Mhóir, agus bhí a cuid bean leobhtha fosta.Aon lá amháin chuaidh Fionn agus na Fianna amach ag seilg agus dubhairt siad le Conán Maoil fan sa bhaile agus an teach a chomhéad. Shíl na mná go n-imreochadh siad cleas ar Chonán. Bhí Conán Maoil an tuirseach agus luighe sé ar an urlár agus thuit sé ina chodladh. Bhí gruaig an-fhada air agus bhí an ghruaig ina luighe ar an urlár.Cheangail na mná an ghruaig do'n philéir agus chuaidh amach, agus thoisigh siad ag déanamh tormáin agus glóir; agus thoisigh siad ag scairtigh "namhaid, namhaid". Mhusgail Conan, agus leis an léim a thug sé d'fhág sé a chuid gruaige agus an chroiceann ina dhiaidh.Bhí an-fhearg air fá dtaoibh de seo agus dubhairt sé go n-imreochadh sé cleas ní b'fhearr ar na mná.Chuaidh sé amach thug leis tuagh agus chuaidh amach. Thug sé aghaidh ar Bharr Choilleadh agus thosigh sé ag cruinnigh brosna.Nuair a bhí na brosna cruinnighthe thug sé a aghaidh ar Mhullán an Tighe Mhóir aríst. Bhí uchtán móir brosna aige agus d'fhág siad san teach iad
(continues on next page)

4428280/4391756/4478429.title: Diarmaid Mac na Baintrí
4428280/4391756/4478429.text:
(continued from previous page)
Chuaid said san a t-ath agus chuaidh mise an clochán, baithead iad san agus thainig mise slán.



Biodh na fianna na gcomhnuidhe i gConnachta agus ba gholl an fear a ba láidre ortha. Thainig said aniar annseo am amhain agus chuir said futha ann.Thainig na Mic Uí Ghorra i dtír agus chuala said iomradh ar na Fianna. Ba mhaith leo fios a bheith aca ar rabh a ngaisge i on churtha le na gcliú.Is cosmhail go rabh eagla ar na Fianna rompa agus d’imthigh Fionn fán chladach (agus) i riocht fear tire ag cur i gcéill go rabh sé ag deánamh cruad acht trágha. Nuair (rabh sé ag deánamh) a thainig na Mic Uí Gorra un chlad-aigh chonnaic said é ag tionntadh na bhfaragán móra ag deánamh gho rabh sé ag sleibhtíu bidh chlad-aigh futha. Chuir a urradh agus a neart iontas (antac) ar na Mic Uí Giorra.Cuireadh goll i luighe sa chliabhán
(continues on next page)

4428266/4389945/4478453.title: (no title)
4428266/4389945/4478453.text:
(continued from previous page)
Oliver on the well for the name of it. I have no prayer that the Saint used to say. Anyone that gave honour to this saint when he died, got very rich.



Once upon a time the English giant heard about Finn Mac Cumhaill being a great warrior so he came over this day to fight Finn. When they met, the shook hands and at last they started to fight. When the English giant saw he was going to be beaten he ran to the sea. Finn Mac Cumhaill ran after him and he put his hands down into the earth and lifted up a heap of earth and threw it after the English giant. It fell in the middle of the Sea and it is called the Isle of Man.



Long ago there was an old master teaching school in Tullynaha. The scholars used to come to his own house and he used to teach
(continues on next page)

4478458/4391868/4478543.title: An Fáth gur Tugadh an tAinm 'Loch Dearg' ar an Loch sin
4478458/4391868/4478543.text:
(continued from previous page)
a chonnaic se an piast shaigh se a ' crozier ' an .    leim an piast isteach san uisge agus snamh leis thart ag deanamh an t-uisge dearg.    Annsin ag leimnigh amach aris ar an  talamh lean se leis ag lubarnaigh agus ag  ' sleamhnú go dtainig se go cnoch i nGleann Finne ag a dtugtar 'Alt na Peiste"               O thaobh an chnuich sin thuit se sios mar ag briseach leabh de'n cnoc leis agus ag tabairt ainm d'on chnoc ceadna o'n la sin go dtí an la indiu.



Cáill óisin fáinne mór agus d'éirigh se
(continues on next page)

4428269/4390288/4479286.title: In Olden Times
4428269/4390288/4479286.text:
(continued from previous page)
dwelling houses were low thatched cottages. Now the most of all the people are trying to see who will have the largest one, and most up to date house.	In other times too there was a very slow conveyance on sea. There was only what they called sailing ships which used to take five and six weeks to go from here to America.



This is a true story telling how Lough Neagh and the Isle of Man was made. Once upon a time Fionn Mac Cumhaill was standing in Antrim and a giant was standing in England. Fionn pulled a big sod. When the sod was pulled it formed the immense hole where Laugh Neagh now stands. He threw the sod meaning to hit the giant in England, but instead of hitting the giant the sod fell in the sea and formed the Isle of Man. My father told me this story.

4428290/4392124/4479411.title: Scéal - Triúr Fear de na Fiannaibh
4428290/4392124/4479411.text:
SgéalTrúir fear de na FiannaibhAndrias Ua DomhnaillDíseartAois 13 blaidhnafuiar mé an sgeal seo anuraidh o Mícheal Ua DomhnaillDíseartAois 70 bliadhna26.7.'38Bí Fionn Mac Cumhaill agus Oisin Mac Fionn agus Goll Moirne triúr fear de na Fiannaibh amuigh ag reilg lá amháin agus bí dha madad leabhtha agus trí gunna. Druid an ceo isteach ortá agus níd nach iongnaidh  cuaidh siad as seachsan.Bál, rubhail siád leo agus fa deireadh conaic siad solas giotá fáda uabta agus tarraing siad air. Nuair a thainig siad comharach go-maith do, chonnaic siad go rabh se amuighar an oilean locha Cairn, Fuair siad bad, Cuaidh isteach ann agussiar go dtí an solas leobhtaí
(continues on next page)

4428312/4393725/4479481.title: Mullán an Tí Mhóir
4428312/4393725/4479481.text:
(continued from previous page)
-ghaoch casgairt cur na dtoighthe da losgadh ar daoinibh. Cur Fionn a órdóg faoi a fhiacal. Fuair sé fior go rabh an teach agus na mna dóighte. Chuaidh Garraidh i bhfodhlach (i bhfolomh). Chodhluigh sé an chead oidhche i n-uaigh sa Gleann Cuaiche. Nuair a tháinig na fir abhaile fuair siad na mna ‘nangrabhar dubha dóighte. Annsin thoisigh na Fianna ag cuartughadh Garraidh acht ní thiocfadh leo é fhagháil. Annsin chuaidh Garraidh siar go Connacht agus chuaidh sé isteach i n-uaigh agus d’fhán sé annsin naoi lá agus naoi n-oidhche gan aon ghreim bídh a fhághail.h-innseadh do mhac Garraidh gur beathadhach fiadhain a bhí ann agus chuaidh sé isteach agus mharbhuigh sé a athair. Annsin d’athu a lámh comh mór sin a’s go bhfuair sé bás.



Sgéal a 3ad (1) Cáit Nic Niallghuis(2) Breacmhaigh, Árd a’Ráth, i dTírchonaill.Agus a 9ad (3) 14 bliadhnaAgus a 10ad (4) (beatha)  Paisde – scoile.(5) As a bhreacmhaigh(6) O’ n-a mathair – tuairim is 12 bliadain óshoim(7) 40 bliadhain(8) An bhreacmhaigh(9) Mi na Bealtaine ‘38
(continues on next page)

4428312/4393736/4479523.title: Scéal fán Fhéinn
4428312/4393736/4479523.text:
Uair amháin bhí Fionn agus a chuideachta 'na gcomhnuidhe i gCéideadh. Tháinig fir ó tír eile le tóir a cur ortha. Ní rabh a fhios ag Fionn caidé dhéanfadh sé. Smaointigh sé ar [bh?]. D'iarr sé ar a chuid fear dhul ar shiúbhal 'na chruic agus go bhanfadh sé féin agus Oscar sa bhaile. Nuair a bhí na coimhighthighe ag teacht chuaidh Fionn isteach sa chliabhán agus chuir sé Oscar siar go dtí an Gleann leis na ba a bhuachailleacht. Tháinig na fir eile isteach agus d’iarr siad ar na mnáibh ca rabh Fionn agus an Fiann. Dubhairt na mná go rabh siad ar shiúbhal ‘na chruic. Chuaidh duine de’na fir go dtí an cliabhán agus cuir a mhéar isteach i mbéal Fhinn. Bhain Fionn an mhéar de, agus ar[?] an fhear “sin páiste maith atá agat”. “Tá sé maith go leor” ars an bhean. Annsin d’iarr siad ar na mnáibh dinnéar a dhéanamh réidh dobhtha. Rinne na mná arán agus chuir siad giota iarainn ann i nganfhios do na coimhighthighe agus nuair a bhí sé réidh shuidh na fir isteach chuig an tabla agus thosuigh ag ithe an aráin. Nuair a d’íosfadh siad giota de bhriseadh siad a gcuid fiacal agus arsa siad san “ní thig linn an t-arán seo a ithe”. Sin an cineál a itheann Fionn agus na fir eile nuair a bhíonn siad ‘sa bhaile ars an bhean. Caithhfidh muidsinne dinnéar de chineál éiginteacht eile a fhághail arsa na fir. D’iarr siad annsin ca rabh na ba. D’innis na mná dobhtha go rabh siad thiar in an Ghleann agus d’imthigh duine aca siar fa choinne buláin fa choinne dinnear a dhéanadh. Nuair a tháinig an fear go dtí Oscar arsa seisean “béidh ceann da na bulláin seo agam”. Ní bhéidh”, arsa Oscar. Fuair an fear greim ar cheann de h-adharcaibh an bhuláin agus fuair Oscar greim ar an cheann eile. Níor stad siad go dtí gur steall siad an bulán siar go ruball. Anois arsa an fear béidh an leath seo agam agus d’imthigh sé arais go dtí an teach go bhfuigheadh sé a dhinnéar. Nuair a bhí an dinnéar ithte aca, chuaidh siad amach. D’iarr siad annsin ar na mnaibh caidé ‘n cineál grinn a bhíodh ag Fionn nuair a bhíodh sé fa’n bhaile. Arsa na mná, “Bíonn sé ag caitheamh na cloiche sin thar mhullach an tighe agus gheibheann sé greim uirthí sul a mbhuaileann sí an talamh ar an taobh eile. Fuair fear
(continues on next page)

4428307/4393348/4480553.title: Eachtra na bhFiann in Ard an Rátha
4428307/4393348/4480553.text:
Lá da rabh Fionn agus na Fianna ag tóruigheacht Dhiarmuid agus Gráinne ar bhantaibh ghlasa Tír Chonaill ca mbuaileadh an oidhche ortha acht iad ag a bhainne ag ceann Báidh Luathrais Big an áit ar a dtugtar anois Mullan Tighe Móir. Bhí dún ag na Fianna annseo agus é arduighthe go máith oscionn cothrom na talamh agus é ciorcalach agus fá thuaram deich dtroighthe in aoirde. Ar mullaich seo bhí an teach acu. Teach mór adhmaid a b'eadh é agus neart coillte ar gach taobh de le fasgadh a deanamh dó.Ca bith bhí na Fianna tuirseach go máith agus ní ró fháda go dteachaidh siad a chodladh acht fágadh Conan Maol ar faire trith na h-oidhche. Cuaid Fioinn agus a chuideacht a chodladh.
(continues on next page)

4428317/4394373/4480864.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill i dTeamhair
4428317/4394373/4480864.text:
Bhí Fionn Mac Cumhail agus na Fianna ag cuir faobhtha i dTeamhair uair amhain. Cuaidh Fionn amach maidin amháin. Chuir sé a órdog in a bheal. Tháinig sé isteach arais. Dubhairt sé leis na Fianna go rabh triobloid mhóir riomhpa anois go cionn bliadhna. Chuaidh sé amach arais. Tháinig (sé isteach) bean mhór roimhe. Dubhairt an bhean leis go mairfeadh sí é mar bhfuighedh sé ceann Rí an Domhain Thoir dithe roimhe bliadhain ó. indiu. Tháinig sé isteach arais agus d’innis sé do na Fianna caidé mar bhí. Dubhairt na Fianna go gcaithfeadh Fionn a ghabhail ar shiubhal. Ní leigfeadh siad fear ar bith leis acht fear amháin. ‘Sé an tainm a bhí ar an fear sin. Tón Iariann gan Tapadh.D’imthigh Fionn agus Tón Iarainn leobhtha. Ní raibh siad i bhfad ag siubhal go bhfaca siad marcach ag tarraingt ortha. Dubhairt Fionn go gcuirfeadh sé ceilbhear ar an mharcach.
(continues on next page)

4481744/4408437/4481227.title: Old Story
4481744/4408437/4481227.text:
Long, long ago a giant lived in Connaught. He held a feast, he invited all his friends. Goll Mac Mórna went to the feast. Goll's brother was a wee Oisin going about spying.Oisin said to Goll Mac Mórna there will be a fight in it and the will be all watching at the door. Oisin told Gool to take the butcher's knife with him. Goll said to Oisin you are always spying something bad. Goll went up to Connaught and he sat down beside the giant. The giant had an arm growing out of his breast.The giant said are there as good men in Donegal as up here. Gool said yes, he played one slap at Goll and missed. He fell to the floor, Goll pulled out the butcher's knife and cut the head of the giant. Goll went out and called on Oisin to come with the steel suit and
(continues on next page)

4481744/4408438/4481229.title: Old Story
4481744/4408438/4481229.text:
(continued from previous page)
and he challenged all Connaught around.The shots were flying off him. Goll came home he went to the far side of Lough Finn. There was a black pig on the far side of the lough, the black pig and Goll were fighting. Oisin's sister was on this side. She heard the noise of Goll and the pig. She lifted two stones in her apron and threw them into the lough to get over. They are there from that day to this day when she went over, Goll had the black pig killed and the pig had Goll killed.



Oisin was going about a poor we man and St, Patrick's maid was going for a bucket of water, she went in and told St; Patrick about the old man, St Patrick told her to take in the poor old man.St; Patrick took him to the highest Mountain when he saw it was Oisin. St; Patrick was going with a crutch. St; Patrick was standing and hed the crutch on the top of Oisin's foot.
(continues on next page)

4428307/4393367/4481392.title: Scéal
4428307/4393367/4481392.text:
(continued from previous page)
iad. Annsin fuair an rí é fhéin bás agus thug sé an talamh uilig do'n fhear bheag.Peadar Ó FuaruisgeMín Teineadh DéArd a RáthSéamuis Ó FuaruisgeMín Teineadh DéArd a Ráth



Bhí Fionn Mac Cumhail ag siubhail thart lá amháin, agus chas sé ar bhean, agus bhí páca cardaí aici. Chuir an bhean ceist ar Fhionn, an rabh sé ag gabhail a imirt cluiche, agus dubhairt sé go rabh.Annsin dubhairt an bhean sul a thoisigh siad, an duine a chaillfeas an cluiche, go gcaithfeadh sé a gabhail go dtí an Domhain Thoir agus
(continues on next page)

4428307/4393379/4481395.title: Scéal
4428307/4393379/4481395.text:
Nuair a Fionn Mach Chumhail pósta chupla bliadhain fuair an bhean bhas agus bhí an bhrón ar Fhionn na diaidh, agus rinn sé suas ina inntin nach bpósfadh sé arist. Acht aon lá amháin chas cailín deas air, agus Gráinne an t-ainm a bhí uirthí. D'iarr Fionn uirthí "An bpósfaidh tú mé" acht dhiúltaigh sí é. Chuaidh Fionn ar an bhomaite go dtí an t-athair a bhí ina rí; agus chuir sé ceist air an dtabharfadh sé cead dó a inghean a phósadh. Thug Cormac cead dó acht ní phósfadh Gráinne é mar shíl sé go raibh sé ró-shean.Ina dhiaidh sin dubhairt sí go bpósfadh sí é, agus rinneadh amach lá an phósta. Nuair a bhí na daoine uilig cruinnuighthe isteach ins a theach an oidhche sin. Bhí gach duine ar meisge acht Gráinne í fhéin. D'amharc sí thart agus chonnaic sí go rabh
(continues on next page)

4428331/4396269/4481511.title: Story of Lough Finn
4428331/4396269/4481511.text:
As Finn & his companions hunted over Ireland the game became scarce & retreated into the wild & well wooded regions of the glens & mountains. Finn pursued them to these haunts and this brought him at length to Glen-Fada-na Shalga, (The long glen of the chases) in Donegal near Glenties. They had travelled all day without seeing a house but as darkness set in they spied a light in Glenleighan south of the Gweebarra river. They drew towards the light & found a man called Leighan living there with his son & daughter.Finn asked for food but the old man, when he saw the large company, shook his head & said he had scarcely enough for his own household but that he would share what he had & added that in the morning he would show them the lair of a wild bull & if they could kill him there would be plenty for all.Finn agreed & they all went to bed for the night, their beds being of heather spread on the earthen floor. All were early astir next morning & Leighan sent his son Feargowan with them to show them the haunt of the wild bull.
(continues on next page)

4428332/4396426/4481670.title: Seanscéaltaí
4428332/4396426/4481670.text:
Dhinny Anna Ní Ghuibhir an sgeal seo domh. Rughadh as togadh í i Largabreach. Chuala Ánna an sgeal o ah athair Brian Mac Guibhir (60 bliadhain.) Largabreach (Feirmeóir). Chaith seisean a shaoghal i Largabreach. Chuala seisean an sgeal ó a mhathair - ní rabh bearla air bith aici.Bhí Fianna Eireann lá amháin ag seilg ar sleibhte na nGleannta. Thainig ceo mór ortha agus chuaidh siad ar seachran. Shuidh siad síos a dheanamh a sgríste agus thainig fear dubh dorcha ionsortha fríd a ceo agus bhí baisceid de ubhallaibh glasa leis ar bhacan a láimhe. Thug sé ceann aca do Goll Mac Morna agus dubhairt Goll gurbh sin an t-ubhall a bhfeárr a dith se ariamh agus thug sé ceann aca thart d’on eile fhear de na Fiannaibh. Annsin dubhairt an fear dubh dorcha dá dtéigheadh siad leis ar feagh lá agus bliadhain go bhfuigeadh siad neart de na h-ublaí sin. Dubhairt Goll Mac Morna go racadh agus siubhal siad leobhtha. Níor mhothuigh siad gorabh siad istigh thall i gcuairt na Beilge agus iad le marbhughadh ag Fianna na Beilge.Bhí fear i nEireann darbh ainm Finn Mac Cumhail agus bhí fios ag Finn Mac Cumhail agus nuair nac rabh na Fianna ag teacht chnag sé ordóg i na bheal agus
(continues on next page)

4428319/4394433/4481906.title: Scéal Fiannaíochta
4428319/4394433/4481906.text:
(continued from previous page)
an Fhir mhóir” mar ainm ar an áit ar thuit sé go dtí an lá atá indiú ann.



Ins an t-sean aimsear bhí baicle saighdúir i n-Éirinn. ar dtugtaoi curaidh na Craoibhe Ruaidhe ortha. Imeasg an sluagh seo bhí fear dar b’ainm Cúchúlainn. Deirtear gur seo an dóigh a bhfuair sé a ainm.Nuair a bhí sé na stócach chuaidh sé ar chuairt chuig gabha dar b’ainm Culainn. Is dóiche go rabh cú crosta aige. Nuair a bhí Cúchulainn ag gabhail in aice an toighe léim an cú air. Thóg an gasúr cloch trom agus chaith sé ar a cú é agus mharbhuigh sé í.Ní rabh Culainn leath shásta nuair a mharbhuigheadh an cú agus bhíodh sé ag mairgnigh
(continues on next page)

4428348/4397779/4483418.title: Loch Dearg
4428348/4397779/4483418.text:
I bhfad ó shin nuair a bí na Fianna i n-Éirinn bhíodh siad amuigh ag seilg ar sléibhte Tíre Conaill. Tháinig siad trasna ar chnámh mhór. Thoisigh siad uilig ag dearcadh caidé'n seórt cnáimh a bhí ann. Bhí poll beag air agus  d'amharc Goll Mac Móirne fríd agus chonaic sé rud beag mar bheadh péist bheag istoigh ann. D'inis sé seo do Fhionn Mac Cumhail. Rinne Fionn fios agus dubhairt sé dá b'fhuigheadh an beathach seo a sháith uisce gurbh é an beathach a bá mó in Éirinn é.
(continues on next page)

4428348/4397783/4483419.title: Na Fianna
4428348/4397783/4483419.text:
Bí dhá dhream Fianna  in Éirinn, Fianna Laighean agus Fianna Connacht. Bá iad Fianna Laighean a bá láidre. Am amháin thug Fianna Chonnacht cuireadh do Fianna Laighean a theacht chun féasta go Beann Bulban i gCo. Sligigh. D'iarr siad orta gan arm ar bith a beith leobhtha. Ghlac Fianna Laighean an  cuireadh agus rinne siad mar d'iarradh ortha, ach nuair a  bí siad ag imeacht dubhairt Goll Mac Moírne go dtabhairfidh seisean leis an "Sgian Ranna" sin an  sgian a rannadh siad an biadh léithe.
(continues on next page)

4428348/4397890/4483618.title: Eachtraí na bhFiann
4428348/4397890/4483618.text:
I bhfad o shoin nuair a bhí na Fianna i n-Éirinn tugadh cuireadh chun féasta dobhtha anonn go Chríoc Lochlann agus d’iarradh ortha gan arm ar bith a thabhairt leobhtha. Dubhairt Goll Mac Móirne gurbh’ fheidir gur cuireadh fille a bhí ann agus go dtabhairfeadh seiseán leis sgian Fionn. Phollfadh an sgian seo rud ar bith agus ní thiocfadh í a lúbadh.Nuair a chuaidh siad i dtír i gCríoch Lochlann cuartughadh iad acht ní bhfuair siad an sgian a bhí le Goll Mac Móirne. Rinneadh réidh féasta mór agus
(continues on next page)

4428348/4397954/4483705.title: An Rí agus na Fianna
4428348/4397954/4483705.text:
Bhí rí ann aon uair amháin agus thug sé cuireadh dó na Fiannaibh a theacht chuig féasta a bhí aige. Tháinig na Fianna go caisleán an ríogh agus nuair a chuaidh siad isteach bhí tábla bréagh i lár an toighe agus cuid mhór cathaoireach thart fa dtaobh de. Bhí cathaoir do’n iomlan acu acht fear amhain agus	sin an fear a ba lugha. B’eigean dó-san suidhe ar an urlár.Sul a shuidh siad síos chróch siad a gcuid claidhimhte ar an bhalla, shuidh siad síos agus d’ith siad agus d’ól siad a sáith. Nuair a bhí siad réidh thug siad iarraidh éirghe ach ní rabh siad ábalta mar bhí siad greamuighthe de na cathaoireacha agus an fear a bhí ar an úrlár bhí seisean greamuighthe fosta.
(continues on next page)

4428349/4398127/4483839.title: Paidir ag Éirí
4428349/4398127/4483839.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



Bhí fionn agus na fianna (agu) ag seilg lá amháin agus ní raibh Goll Mac Moirne leobhta. Bhí sé na codhlad san am. Rinne mna na bfiadhan amach gur mhaith an rud cleas a imirt air. Ní tiocfadh Goll a musgladh go ndeanfaidh rud a dtugtaí conairteacha air le madaidh. Cheangal siad gruag ghuill ar creataí an toigh agus cuaidh siad amach leis na madaidh go musglad siad Goll. Nuair a thoisig na madaidh a thafann. Léim Goll anairde
(continues on next page)

metadata.Address: Croaghgorm or Blue Stack Mountains, Co. Donegal

4428109/4378842/4485263.title: An Charraig Bhuí
4428109/4378842/4485263.text:
The 'Carraig Buidhe' or 'yellow rock' is supposed to be thrown from 'Rinn-Crúdha' point by bicin.There is another rock nearby it which was said to be thrown back by Fionn Mac Cumhaill and which is called "the round stone".



The 'Carraig Buidhe' is situated on the left bank of the River Blackwater about one mile from Youghal Bridge. Near this rock is a well called 'Tobar Bό Fiune' which means 'the well of the fairy cow'.This cow came to give milk to the people of the place, but one day a selfish woman came and milked the cow into a sieve. When the cow saw
(continues on next page)

4428342/4397060/4485668.title: Scéal
4428342/4397060/4485668.text:
(continued from previous page)
Dhomhnaill ar shiubhal ortha le dá chloich déag bhraith. Fuair siad fhad le Cruach an Airgid.



Bhí athair Fhinn Mhic Chumhail faoi gheasa. Thiocfadh é a chur 'un bháis. D'imthigh siad agus thug siad leobhtha inghean an rí, an bhean a ba doigheamhla in éirinn. D'fhág siad amuigh ag na farragáin (residence) í. Nuair a tháinig athair Fhion ann thuit sé i ngrádh léithe. Dubhairt sé léithe go mbairfidhe eiseoin anois ag dá mbéadh mac aicí aire maith a thabhairt do, agus dá mbéadh inghean aicí cead a réir a dhéanamh léithe. D'imthigh inghean an rígh agus rinne sí margadh le Cailleach na gcearc.Dá bhfagadh sí mach go dtabhairfadh cailleach na gcat léithe é agus go dtógfadh sí é.Bhí cúpla ann, giorsach agus gasúr. Rugadh an ghiorsach an chead uair. Agus thóg na mná a n-intinn díthe. Tháinig an mac 'un t-saoggaidh (saoghail?) annsin. Chuir sí an dara páisde i mbasgad agus d'fhág sí suas ag Cailleach na gCearc é.D'imthigh Cailleach na gCearc agus rinne sí margadh le suineir teach folaigh a dhéanamh dithe fhéin agus don leanbh. D'imthigh an siuineir agus rinne
(continues on next page)

4428342/4397062/4485669.title: Seanphisreogaí
4428342/4397062/4485669.text: Nuair a bhíos na bric ag leimnigh s'an uisge sin comhartha fearthainne.Nuair a bhíos plód cuileogaí ag an fhuinneóg sin comhartha fearthainne fosta.Nuair a bhíos na cuileogaí ag dul thart ar mhullach poill uisge sin comhartha fearthainne.Nuair a bhíos an-rud mioltóg san aer sin comhartha fearthainne fosta.Nuair a bhíos cuid mhór seanfáin eiteogach ar an bhealach mhór sin comhartha fearthainne, ach corr uair tig siad le aimsear Má thig spideóg isteach go teach agus guan é na chleachtadh aicí deirtear go fuigh duine éigin bás sa teach sin go fóill.Má tchíd duine dhá snag-bhreac ar maidin sin comhartha mí-adha.Má tchíd duine dhá snag-bhreac sin comhartha ádha.Níl áird ag duine ar bith ar an dreoilán no nuair a bhí ar Slánuightheoir ag dul go Egypt agus nuair a bhí na saighdiuirí da chuartughadh bhí an dreolán arthaobh an bhealaigh mhóir agus d'fhiacfruigh siad do na daoine a'n bhfacaidh siad ar Slánuightheoir.

4428343/4397080/4485715.title: Deireadh na bhFiann
4428343/4397080/4485715.text:
Deireadh na bhFianRéamh-Rádh - Mar-an-gceadna.An Sgéal.Tús:  Ní rabh mé fhéin ariamh gan sgéal-úr nó sean-sgéal. Da mbéidhinn gan aon sgéal, chumfainn fhéin sgéal, nó rachainn na Frainnce fa dhéin sgéil. Da mbéidhinn bódhar ní chluinnfinn é, 'sda mbéidhinn balbh ní thiocfadh liom é innse ach nuair atá sé agam innseochaidh mé é.Bhí sin ann ibhfad oshoin agus ibhfad oshoin fhéin é. Nuair a thainig Niamh Chinn Óir go h-Éirinn ar lorg Oisín thug sí sgian do na Fianna darbh' ainm dí "An Sgian-Ranna" agus "muna leagtar an sgian sin ach ar cheathramhadh d'fhiadh gheóbhadh seacht gcátha na bhFian a sáith."Chuaidh na Fianna amach a sheilg lá amháin agus an sgian-ranna leóbhtha. Ní dheachaidh siad abhfad gur mharbh siad fiadh. Rinn siad teine, rós an fiadh, rinn codtracha de leis an sgin agus fuair iomlán aca a sáith.D'imthigh siad leóbhtha. Thainig siad fhad le
(continues on next page)

4428357/4399183/4486209.title: Goll agus na Siógaí
4428357/4399183/4486209.text:
Goll agus na SíodheogaíLá amháin, bhí na Fianna ag imtheacht a sheilg agus Goll Mac Móirne leo.  Thug siad uilig fa dear go raibh Goll ag fanacht 'un deiridh giota maith.Bhí a fhios a Goll go riabh sídheógaí ar an cnoc agus bhí eagla air go gcuirfheadh siad faoi draoidheacht é.  Níor mhaith leis sin a innse do na Fianna mar bhí eagla air go ndeirfheadh siad gur cladhaire a bhí ann.Fa dheireadh tháinic na sídheógaí ar amharc.  Triúr aca a bhí ann.Shuidh na Fianna síos ar carraigeacha ag coimhead ortha.  Tháinic siad comhgarach do na Fianna agus chuir troid ortha acht nuair a d'fiach na Fianna le h-eirighe, ní raibh siad ábalta iad fhéin a sgathadh ar shiubhal ó na caraigeacha.
(continues on next page)

4428358/4399395/4486323.title: Scéal
4428358/4399395/4486323.text:
(continued from previous page)
Bhí Paidí réidh leó leobhtha. Crochadh an fear a marbh an bhean agus díbreadh an bheirt eile ar sáile.Sgéalaidhe: Domhnall Ó Domhnaill, Tullaigh, Clochán Liath.Aois: 71 bliadhain.Sgríobhnóir: Brighid Nic Amhalaoidh, Tullaigh.

D’éirigh siad amach an maidin amháin a dheánamh seilg’ maiden, agus mór-sgaramhaint sléibhe. D’imthigh siad leó fríd cnuic agus sléibhte.D’imthigh fear soir agus siar. Níor fhan

4428353/4398663/4487153.title: Scéal
4428353/4398663/4487153.text: Bhí Rí in Éireann agus Fionn ar b'ainm do agus Bran an t-ainm a bhí air. Bhí sé iongantach ceanamhail do. Lá amáin bí na fir tuirseach agus comhnuidhe siad ar barr cnuic agus bí sé ag dul síos go dtí an fairrge. Bí fhios acu go raibh sé an áit iongantach dansearach bhí achan rud uaigneach ann nó bhí sidheóg ann. Ar maidín lá ar na mbarach chuaidh siad amach agus bá mhaith leis an sidheóg dá mbeadh Bran aice le rudaí a congbuil o’n a thig faoi’n fhairrge. Chonnaic na madadh gearrfiadh agus rith sé na diaidh. Sgairt Fionn ar an madadh ach níor cuala sé é lean sé an gearrfiadh. Sgairt sé aríst ach ní chuala sé é. Nuair a thainig sé go dtí an fairrge an sideóg a bhí ann agus fuair sé greim air agus thug isteach é agus bí brón mór ar Fionn na diaidh.

4428369/4400284/4487831.title: Na Fianna agus an Fathach Coimhthíoch

4498309/4383854/4498335.title: Story (Old Tale)
4498309/4383854/4498335.text: (130)Story (Old Tale).Skerries, Co. Dublin. In a field at Balcunnin two miles from Skerries, there is a tall stone shaped somewhat like a man. It is said that a fairy queen was going to Fionn Mac Cumhail when a man leapt out of a hedge and tried to seize her. Like magic a hazel rod appeared in her hand and she turned her man into a rock. John Fox,9, Strand St.,Skerries.From:- R. Dunne,The Hills. (Died Since).

4498347/4383946/4498352.title: Local Heroes
4498347/4383946/4498352.text: From time to time there were local heroes in Rush.  Back in the time of the Black and Tans many of the Rush men fought for their country.  John McCann was one of these.  He was dragged out of his house and shot before his own door.  He lived at the Handpark.Larry Plunkett who is living in Hayestown lifted a hundred weight in his mouth.  Long ago Fionn Mac Cumhaill is supposed to have taken a step from Lambay Island to Kenure House and his footprint is left on the doorstep.Long ago the people used to walk to Ballinasloe. Every year a fair was held there. Cattle, sheep and horses were sold there.

4498641/4385211/4498650.title: (no title)
4498641/4385211/4498650.text:
Written by Rita Purcell (aged 10)Park VillaCastleknock Co DublinTold to her by her brother Ml.(?) PurcellHe heard it from his Grandmother Mrs Dempsey (over 70)Park VillaCastleknock Co DublinCastlekock is called Cnuca. At the present time beside the collage the ruins of the castle can still be found. A good many years a go during the time of Finn MacCumall. Finn and Con had an argument as to who owned the castle. They decided to have a battle.Both armies had to come half way and so they met at Castleknock. Finn was killed and Con won the battle.

4461441/4395062/4499143.title: Seilg Ghleann Léithín
4461441/4395062/4499143.text:
Bhí sin ann ibhfad ó choin nuair a ghannuigh an t-seilg ar Fiannaibh Éireann i nGleann na Smól, smaoithigh Fionn go mbfeárr do tarraingt an Ghleann Fhada na Sealg. Nuair a tháinig siad fhad le loch Finne, bhí an oidhche orthu agus thionntuigh siad sios ar thaobh na láimhe clí bealach Gleann Léichinn. Chonnaic siad solus agus thárraing siad air. Bhí bóthog deánta sa’ tsliabh agus fear n-a chomhnuidhe ann, dar b’ainm do Leichinn. Bhí mac agus ingean aige, Feardómhain a bhí ar an mac agus Finngheal ar an ingean.Dubhairt Fionn go rabh ocras orthú agus d’fiafruigh siad do an rabh fhios
(continues on next page)

4428337/4396591/4499693.title: Diarmuid agus Gráinne
4428337/4396591/4499693.text: Diarmuid agus GrániaPádraig  Mac Giobúin    Mar ar leath 10Bhí dream le Diarmuid agus Gránia 'na gcomhnuidhe i bpoll ins na Cruachaibh Gorma. Tháinig eagla ortha agus dubhairt siad go rabh Fionn agus na Fianna ag teacht agus d'imthigh Diarmuid agus Gránia. D'fhan an chuid eile. Nuair a bhi siad ag teacht isteach 'barr an Ailt Deirg mhothuigh siad an buithrigh ag an bhunadh eile, nó tháinig na siaghdiúirí agus mharbh siad deireadh aca. Chuaidh Diarmuid agus Gránia fhad le h-áit  a rabh beanntreacha thart fa dtaobh de. Sháruigh sé ar na Fianna iad a fhághail. Deirtear go bhfuair siad bás annsin. Tá an t-ainm Leabaidh Dhiarmuda agus Gránia ar an áit ó shoin.

4428337/4396596/4499701.text:
Sgéal : - Loch FinneAmras Ó Caoimhghín- Mín na Sróine                                                   Na Cruacha                                                   An Clochán                                                   LeithbhearrAos 51Tógadh é  5 mhíle ón ait thuas agus fuair sé seo ó na athair nuair a bhí sé 12 d'aois.Bhí seanduine ina chómhnuidhe le na mhac Forghamhain agus le na inghean Finngheal i gcró fód cómhgharach ag Loch Finne, atá istigh i lár shleibhte Thír Chonaill. Bhí na Fianna ag dul thart  'seilg cómhgharach ag an loch lá amháin. Ní raibh sgian na ranna leo agus nuair nach raibh ní thiocfadh leo mórán seilge a dhéanamh. Tháinig an-ocras ortha agus rinne siad amach go mb'fheárr tarraingt ar an chnó go bhfeicfeadh siad an bhfuighidh siad aon rud le h-ithe. Rinne . Dubhairt an seanfhear leo nach raibh rud ar bith aige-san le tabhairt dóibh ach ar seisean "Tá fhios ag mo mhac áit a bhfuil tarbh allta 7 rachaidh sé libh agus thig libh é a mharbhadh" Chuaidh Forghamhain leo agus theasbáin an tarbh dóibh ach theip ar na Fianna uilig a mharbhadh. Annsin chuaidh an Forghamhain de léim ar dhruim an tairbh agus ní raibh i bhfad gur mharbh sé é. Reannadh an tarbh ina cheithre cheathramhna
(continues on next page)

4428327/4395540/4500720.text:
Sceál"Oísín i dTír na n-Óg".Lá dá ráb Fíonn Mac Cumaill agus a gcuid fear ag cois na faírrge, connac siad ag teair tiocfad anall ar an faírrge moír cailín aláinn agus i ag marcuigeair ar capall bán. Nuair a taínig sí deir cuaid sí'un cainnce le fíonn agus d'ínnis sí dó gur Naom Cinn óir a h-ainm. Nuair a connaic sí Oísín glac sí dúit ann agus d'innis sí dó fear gur maíc leíre a mac Oísín a pósfad agus a tabairc leíre go Tír na n-Óg. 4427863/4351651/4504562.title: Feenone
4427863/4351651/4504562.text:
Ag breathnú ar léir-sgáil na h-Éireann feicfidh tú Scoith Imligh, an Scoith atá ag gobadh amach ag an gcoirnéal atá siar o dheas de Chuan Mogha taobh thiar de Conndae Mhuigheó. Cúpla míle taobh o dheas aríst de'n Scoith, tá baile fearainn a tugtar "Feenone" air i mBéarla, ag sineadh on bFairrge Mhóir isteach go bun Maol Réidh, an sliabh is aoirde sa gconndaé. Baile Fearainn an fhada seadhe acht tá stráice de caillte anois agus toigthe isteach ag bailte eile in aice na fairrge. Mar is léir ó'n méid tir-eolais seo, tá ceann an bhaile in a phortach bun sléibhe agus ceann eile in a dhumhach gainimh cois trágha. Tá  dá leabhaidh Dhiarmada ann go foill, ceann in aice  na fairrge agus ceann isteach sa bportach, ar an gceann eile, an  bhaile ceithre míle ó'n a chéile agus an baile fearainn "Feenone" ag síneadh amach eatorra.Seo mar a fuair an baile a ainm. Nuair a bhí Fionn agus an Fhiann ag tóraidheacht Dhiarmuda agus Gráinne tháinig siad chomh fada le baile eile sa gceanntar a tugtar "Áit Thíghe na bhFiann" air fos sa
(continues on next page)

4498682/4385589/4509852.title: Castleknock
4498682/4385589/4509852.text: There was a castle on the top of the hill right in front of where Castleknock College is now.  There was a battle on the top of the hill between Conn of the Hundred Battles and Cumhal father of Fionn Mac Cumhal.  The castle is nearly all knocked down but some of the ruins are still there and there is a tunnel from where the castle was, to Mulhuddard Churchyard and that is how Castleknock got its name.

4428390/4403326/4511498.title: Scéal fá na Fianna
4428390/4403326/4511498.text: Tháinig dream d'fhir laidire fá choinne troid a chuir ar na Fianna. Bhí eagla ar na Fianna go bhfuigheadh siad an bhuaidh orthu agus smaointigh siad ar seift. D'imthigh cuid aca amach a sheilg. Chuaidh Goll a'bhuachailleacht agus Conan a luighe sa chliabhan.Thainig na fir agus chuir siad ceist ar Goll cá rabh na Fianna. Dubhairt siad go rabh siad ag seilbh acht nach mbeadh ibhfad go bpillfeadh siad. D'iarr siad an bhológ air acht ní thabharfadh Goll dobhtha é. Bheir siad greim adhairce uirthi agus rinne siad dhá leath díthe ó chlár a h-éadan go bárr a rubaill.Chuaidh siad isteach 'un toighe annsin agus bhí iongantas ortha go mór agus bhí an leabh. Bhí an ghaoth isteach sa doras agus d'iarr siad ar bhean a 'toighe an doras eile a fhoscladh. "Ó" arsa sise, "nuair a thiocfas na fir isteach athróchaidh siad thart an teach". "Ma's sin mar tá" arsa na fir "tá an t-am againne bheith ar shiubhal"

Bhi fear ann i n-am amháin agus sé an t-ainm a bhi air Garbh Mór. Bhi sé i n-a chómhnuidhe i n-áit a dtugtaoi Las-na-Rón air thall sa Tuirc. Chualaidh sé iomrádh ar Fhianna Éireann agus smaointigh sé go dtiocfadh sé anall go dtabhairfeadh se leis anonn lasta luinge aca go ndíolfadh sé thall sa Tuirc iad mar sglábhuidhthe. Tháinig, Chuir sé a dhruim le crann an t-soithigh agus bhí sé ag stiúradh an bháid le na ladhair mhoir. Nuair a tháinig sé go dtí an cladhach chuir an laoch an long faoi n-a ascail agus tháinig isteach ar thalamh thirm.Chonnaic na Fianna é ag teacht agus ghlac siad eagla roimhe agus smaointigh siad go mb'fheárr díobhtha fear a chur 'un cainnte

Bhí cailín beag ag dul chun an t-siopa leis an tóirneach thoisigh an fhearrthainn acht sa deireadh siabadh amach chun na h-abhna í agus ní fhacthas ní ba mhó í. Bhí teach ceann-tuigheadh ar thaoibh cnuic agus stealladh an taobh amach as; b'éigean daobhtha a ghabhail go toigh na comharsan agus codladh go maidín ann. Bhí saighneáin ins an áird thoir-thuaidh seachtmhain roimh theacht na stoirme.



Cailleadh beirt fhear as Bun an Inbhir leis an stoirm. Is dócha go rabh siad amuigh ag ceangal a gcuid cruach agus thóg an ghaoth léithe suas iad amach chun na fairrge móire, agus bhí toighthe a chaill a gceann fosta. Leagadh crainn annseo agus annsiúd fríd an cheanntar. Leagadh crann ar bhean arbh ainm díthe Eibhlín Mhór do bhí na comhnuidhe thuas i gCnoc an Léithid, agus ar maidín an lae sin fuaireas marbh í ag bun crainn. Siabadh an cochán amach chun na fairrge móire agus tháinig cuid de isteach ar an chladach i n-Oileán Toraighe agus é na luighe ar an mharc. Cailleadh fuireann as na h-Oileáin Thiar fosta giota beag ar an taobh thiar de Bhun an Inbhir. Chuaidh siad amach ar maidín an lae sin a thógáil potaí gliomach agus bhí an mhaidín do bhí ann fiadhanta ag bád ar bith le bheith ar bhárr na fairrge. Níor mhaith leis na créatúir a gcuid eangach agus a gcuid potaí gliomach a bheith ar shiubhal leis an
(continues on next page)

4428401/4404904/4512871.title: Oisín i ndiaidh na bhFiann
4428401/4404904/4512871.text:
"Oisín 'ndiaidh na bFiann"." Lá amhain fadó ó shoin bhí na Fianna Éireann, thuas i lár na h-Éireann ag seilg. Nuair a bhí  an lá thuas acú shuidh siad síos cois locha a dheanamh a sgithiste.Bhí  an ghrian ag soillsiú siar fríd an loch. Dubhairt duine acú leis an duine eile, cé a leanadh de'n t-soillsiú deas sin thiocfadh sé isteach go dtí áit dheas eignteacht . Eadar  sin agus léir chonnaic siad ball geal ag tarraingt ortha. Shilfeá gur beathach bán a bhí ann agus marcach mná air. Nuair a tháinig sí fhad leobtha. " Is bréagh an gaiscidheach thú " adubhairt  sí le Fionn Mac Cumhall. " Mise Méadhbha na Gruaige Ruaidhe. agus tá  mo athair 'na rí ar Thír na  h-Óige, agus tháinig mé le do mhac Oisín, a thabhairt liom agus mo bhfágaim é ní phosfaidh mé a'n fhear eile. "Tabhair léim ar mó chúl na níl mise ag gabhal a fhanacht níos fúide". Thug Óisín léim 'un tosaigh gan eagla ar bith. Thug leim ar a cúl. D'fhág slán ag Fionn agus  a mhór shlóighthe. D'imthigh siad leobha ins na  rí ruagán 's na ruagán reatha, 's na  rí ruagán, 's  na rí ruagán 's na  ruagán reatha  na mbéirfeadh siabán de'n ghaoith
(continues on next page)

4428363/4400119/4514884.title: Leabaidh Dhiarmuda
4428363/4400119/4514884.text: Fad ó shoin nuair a bhí na Fianna ag gabhail . Bhí fear aca darbh ainm Diarmuid . Fear iongantach dóigheamhail a bhí ann. Bhí cáilín darbh ainm Gráinne . Bhí sí gabhail a phósadh Fionn acht nuair a chonnaic sí Diarmuid thuit sí i ngrádh leis agus pósadh iad . D'imigh siad ar siubhail . Nuair a fuair  Fionn amach sin chuaidh sé  amach fríd an tír go bheicfeach sé  dtiocfadh leis Diarmuid a fhághail go dtabharfadh sé  greádadh maith do . Bhí  Diarmuid ag  gabhail thart o áit go h áit go dtí go rabh sé thíos i gClochglas agus codhlaidh siad ar láftan ar bhárr binne os cionn na fairrge . Ó'n lá sin go dtí an  la indiú  níor tugadh ainm ar bith ar an áit sin acht Leabhaidh  Dhiarmuida.

4428404/4404914/4514967.title: An Old Story
4428404/4404914/4514967.text:
"An Old Story"One day Saint Columba was walking along the road with a companion. They met a man who was very poor and was going to live on a different farm. The Saint inquired where he was going, and when he heard it, he said to his companion "I give him my curse"They walked on about a mile when they met another man who was very rich and was going to live on another farm. Again the Saint asked where he was going, and when he was told, he said "I give him my curse also"His companion asked him why he gave both men his curse, and the reply was "I curse the first he did not change in time, and I cursed the second because he was well enough, and did not stay where he was."Frances BuchananClaggan, Churchill,Co. Donegal
(continues on next page)

4493644/4407354/4515425.title: Seanscéal
4493644/4407354/4515425.text:
Tá cuid mhór scéaltaí ag muinntir na h-áite seo fá dtaobh de Fhionn Mac Cumhail, Oisín agus na Laochraí eile. Tá scéal ag muinntir na h-áite seo fá Gholl Mac Mórna. Deir siad go bhfuair se bás ar charraic amuigh sa'n fhairrge darbh' ainm, "Carraig Ghoill". Bhí Laochrai eile ag iarraidh Goll a mharbhuighidh agus theich sé. Lean na Laochraí é. Sa deireadh thainic sé fhad leis an fhairrge agus chonnaic se an charraic seo.Snámh sé amach fhad leis agus shuidh sé uirthí. Ni rabh na Laochraí eile maith ag snámh agus d'fhan siad ar an tráigh ag fanacht leis a theacht isteach. Bhí siad ag fanacht le tamall mhaith agus ní rabh se ag teacht isteach. Amuigh ar an charraig bhí Goll ag fagháil bháis leis an ocras, agus leis an fhuacht. Fá dheireadh fuair se bas sa'n áit in a rabh sé na shuidhe. Shíl na Laochraí a bhí ar an traigh go rabh sé 'na chodladh.Fuair siad bád agus
(continues on next page)

4493637/4406417/4515627.title: Seanscéal
4493637/4406417/4515627.text:

hold on to the rock until he would get into the place.   He saw a hand coming out of the rock.   It struck him on the face.   He turned back and never went to fish on a rock again.



The Fianna made boats with broad bottoms so that they could go over shallow water as well as deep water. Once upon a time there were cows grazing beside a wood.  When the men went out to take in the cows at night to be milked they could not get the cows. They went home and told the people of the
(continues on next page)

4493637/4406418/4515628.title: Seanscéal

(continued from previous page)
house that they could not get the cows.   When the man of the house got up next morning the cows were standing at this door.   He milked them and then put them into the field.Once upon a time there were some turf out on a hill.  The owner used to go out for a bag full.   But one day a strange thing happened.   When he went out to the hill he saw that the turf were going were going farther away so he went home.



The old people have no stories about Oisín. The
