4493642/4406678/4517342.title: Rosguill - How Rosguill Got its Name
4493642/4406678/4517342.text:
When the Fianna  were in Ireland long ago it happened that there was a dispute between Finn and Goll. Fionn was the chieftan of the Fianna and for this reason Goll had to retreat so Fionn immediately pursued.  Goll retreated until he came to this parish and he went down to Downings. So Fionn followed him and Goll was obliged to swim out to a rock about a mile from the land. Fionn waited for a fortnight, but at last he went away although he left a man to wait for Goll unknown to Goll himself.At last he decided he would return to land for he was weak with hunger for he drank nothing but salt water. When he returned he came in contact with his enemy who was still waiting. As soon as they met the rushed at each other and fierce battle ensued. The  both killed each other and for this reason the parish is called Rosgoll or Rosgull which is Irish. The rock is called Golls-rock in remembrance of him.
(continues on next page)

4493642/4406680/4517344.title: Story
4493642/4406680/4517344.text:
StoryOnce upon a time a big giant lived at Muckish Mountain, whose name was Oisin. A wild beast lived in a cave in the side of the mountain and it had a horn on its nose, this animal killed all the pigs, sheep and cattle belonging to the people who lived about.This big giant had an axe and a spear. One day he said, he would go up the mountain and kill the animal. Next morning the giant arose very early, took his axe and his spear with him and went out to kill the animal.He sat down to rest near the animal's cave, but he was not long (sleeping) sitting when he fell asleep, when he awoke he looked up and there standing above him was the large animal. He stared at the beast a while, then like the shot of a gun he was off as fast as his long legs would carry him. Indeed the people began to laugh and make fun of him.Next day he went up again to kill
(continues on next page)

4493646/4407268/4522875.title: Ros Goill
4493646/4407268/4522875.text:
Fad ó shoin nuair a bhí na Fíanna in Éirinn, thuirt Goll agus Fionn amach le céile, agus b'éigean do Gholl imthecht. Lean sé é go rabh siad ins an Pharraisde seo. Nuair a mhothuigh Goll iad ag techt, chuidh sé amach ar charraig a bhí amuigh san fhairrge.Bhí an charraig cuairim míle amuigh san fhairrige, agus ní rabh na Fianna abalta fhághail amach fhad leis. Sa deireadh d'eirigh siad tuirseach ag fanacht leis theacht amach arais. Chuir Fionn bean Ghoill amach le biadh chuige, acht bhí Goll faoi gheasaibh gan a dháth a dhéanamh a dh'iarrfadh bean
(continues on next page)

4493686/4410659/4523575.title: Daoine Cáiliúla - Fir Láidre
4493686/4410659/4523575.text:
(continued from previous page)
agus d'innsigheadh dó ná Catoilicigh nuair a bhéadh  ná saighdiuirí ag teacht  ar a dtoír.



Tá cloch thíos ar Tráigh Stocair agus bheirtear   "Cloch Fhinn Mhic Cumhaill" uirthí. Deirtear gur chaith Fionn í ó Inis Eoghain thrasná ná Súilighe.Tá cloch in Ara Aodhaire a bheirtear an "Cloch Mhór" uirthí. Deirtear gur chaith Fionn í fosta ó Inis Eoghain.Deirtear go bhfuil fear de ná Fiannaibh curtha ar bhárr Chnoc Murrin. Tá scéal ag ná sean daoine go dtainic fear dé ná Fiannaibh ó'n saoghal eile agus nuair a chonnaice sé an méid abhí ins ná fir a bhí annseo thoisigh sé ag gaíridhe agus rinn sé oiread gháiridhe is go bhfuair sé bás. Cuireadh é ar bhárr an chnuic.Tá áit  ar an taoibh eile dé'n Mhaoil Ruaidh dar b'ainm Ros Goill. Deirtear gur ó Goll Mac Mórna fear de ná Fianaibh a fuair an aít  a h-ainm.

4493697/4412003/4525035.title: Scéal - Mar a Fuair Conán Maol a Ainm
4493697/4412003/4525035.text: Bhí na Fiannaibh amuigh ag seilg lá amháin agus chonnaic siad caisleán mór. Bhí dhá dhoras ar an chaisleán - ceann ar an chúl agus ceann ar thoiseach. Chuaidh siad isteach agus shuidh siad acht ní rabh siad i bhfad ina suidhe go bfacaidh siad an doras ag imtheacht de'n chúl agus an ghaoith ag teacht ins an doras eile.D'éirigh siad le dhul amach acht ni rabh siad ábalta no bhí siad sáithte ins na cathaoireachaibh. Thainig fear eile de na Fiannaibh agus bhí sé ag dul isteach acht sgairt siadsan leis fanacht amuigh no go rabh siad faoi geasa. Rinne sé sin acht d'iarr siad air fosta a dhul síos go dtí an chaorann agus nuair a tcífeadh sé néal ag dul thart sgaoileadh leis no gur trí mac ríghte a bhí ionnta. D'iarr siad air an fhuil a dhórtughadh sé cuid di a chuimilt ar a bhonnaibh agus an cuid eile a thabhairt leis agus a chuimilt orthasan.Chuaidh sé go dtí an chaorthann agus níor b'fhada go dtainig sé arais agus an fhuil leis agus chuimil ortha é. Acht ní rabh go leór aige fa choinne fear darb' ainm Conal agus shíl siad gur mhór an truaighe é a fhágailt agus tharraing siad as an chathaoir é. D'fhág sé cuid de a chroiceann ins an chathaoir agus ó'n lá sin go dtí an lá indiu "Conal bhuidhe sgálta a tugtar air.

4493703/4412707/4528367.title: How Lough Finn Got its Name
4493703/4412707/4528367.text:
Once upon a time the Fianna Eireann lived in Connaught. One day when they were out hunting they came to a place called Glen Leighan in Co. Donegal. A man named Leighan ruled this place. He had a daughter named Finngeal and a son named Fear Ghamhain. The Fianna went into their house and as they were hungry they asked for something to eat. When they had finished the meal Leighan told the Fianna that there was a wild bull on Achla mountain and that he wished them to go and kill it. They agreed to go and Fear Ghamhain went with them
(continues on next page)

4493752/4416994/4530580.title: Old Irish Tales
4493752/4416994/4530580.text: Diarmuid ODuilhne was married to the daughter of King Cormac Mac Art. Fionn Mac Cool wanted to marry her but she had no fancy in him. So he went to her brother and asked him to give her to him and he said yes. But she dreamt of this red haired man and she went to meet him and the two got married. Fionn Mac Cool began to fight about this and give hot persaude after Diarmuid ODuilhne. He followed him for days and days. Now at last he got into a cave him and his wife Eve. Fionn Mac Cool was for killing them but he never got him again. He had no peace hiding here and there. The King was angry with himself and he chased him away out of his place.

4493755/4416885/4531073.title: The Fianna
4493755/4416885/4531073.text:
There is a flat stone in a place   called the Green Hill. There is a shape of a man's head on each side of it. It was thrown by on of the Fianna while training. It is a yard long and a foot broad. The Fainna camped on that field. They trained every morning and ran a great number of miles before they got anything to eat.



There are only about five tailors in the town and it is said there are none through the country. They work in their homes and in shops they have in the
(continues on next page)

4493755/4416887/4531076.title: Clothes Made Locally
4493755/4416887/4531076.text:
(continued from previous page)
pieces to make shirts out of them. Sometimes a shirt might be three or four colours because of the colours of the pieces. Many shirts are made throughout the district from flour bags also. There is no cloth made now out of flax but there was very much made out of it long ago.



There is a Giants den up in Gransha and it is said to be a den where Diarmuidh and Grania hid when Fionn was chasing them. It is said that Fionn had a thumb of knowledge and if he would
(continues on next page)

4493780/4419946/4537968.title: The Bed of Diarmuid and Gráinne
4493780/4419946/4537968.text: There is a local story told about a place in this district. It is said to be the bed of Diarmuid and Grainne. It is situated in the town-land of Carrowmore. It lies about halfway between the village of Carrowkeel and Carndonagh. It is situated between the parish of Carndonagh and Iskaheen. It consists of a round mound with a bed like shape in it and near to this place is a rock with bones under it which is said to be the bones of Diarmuid and Grainne. Diarmaid who was one of the Fianna of long ago. He was an out-law, and is believed to have often been seeking refuge in the mountains, and lonely places, and Grainne was his wife. The land on which this bed is situated, belongs to a farmer named Philip O'Donnell. It is also situated between the parish of Iskaheen and Buncrana. This mound lies to the left hand side of the Carndonagh road. It lies above P Philip O'Donnell's house out in the hill.

4493807/4423128/4538509.title: Finn's Finger Stone
4493807/4423128/4538509.text:
Finn Mac Cumhaill is supposed to have thrown a stone from Lagacurry, the Isle of Doagh across to Knockamany. The stone is still standing. It resembles a finger in shape. That is how it gets its name.



This is a standing stone about 30' high. It is in Knockamany near Finn's Finger Stone.



These rocks are round Knockamany strand.(1) Rab's Rock(2) Kate's Rock(3) Sloak Rocks(4) Pickens Rocks(5) Diver's Rock(6) The Stook(7) The Squilt is a big cleft in the rock.(8) The Wild Cat's Rock is in Goorey near this school.

4493810/4423072/4539076.title: Giants
4493810/4423072/4539076.text:
There was once a giant named Jack Doherty who lived in Killourt.  This man had no cows or horses and had no farmyard manure and so had to put out seaweed for his piece of land.He used to carry it in a creel to the highwater and dry it there.In one of the gulfs that he used to carry the seaweed from was a big rock which always marred him filling it.  One day Jack got angry because he had to go round the rock to get the seaweed.  He lifted the rock which was about 8 ton and left a gulf which is known yet as Jack Doherty's gulf.



Cumhail, one of the chief leaders of the Fianna was at the Castle of Carraighe Bhraithe on his way to Malin Head. Before leaving, he threw his chair across the bay, so that he might not have to carry it with him. The chair fell on the shore at the foot of Binn Bán, a distance of about three miles from where it was threw fromThe chair is still to be seen in the form of a rock and is known as Cathair na gCumhail. The chair is situated at the entrance of a cave  which is believed to have been Cumhail's palace.Maggie DohertyMuckla

4493810/4423072/4539077.title: Giants
4493810/4423072/4539077.text:

4493810/4423081/4539147.title: A Giant Story - Finn Mc Cumhaill
4493810/4423081/4539147.text: Once upon a time a Giant named Finn Mc Cumhail was walking on top of Dunaff hill.There was a rock there weighing one ton and somebody asked him how far he could throw it.  He lifted it and threw it and it landed at Port na Halloway near the Devil's Bridge in Malin Head about ten miles from where he stood.It is there visible from that day to this day with the print of his four fingers and thumb on it.

4540646/4421875/4544098.title: (no title)
4540646/4421875/4544098.text:
(continued from previous page)
smoke.



Once upon a time there was an old warrior in Ireland called Fionn Mac Cumhail.This giant was known all over Ireland for his great deeds. Once he planted a row of large stones in the direction of Moville. It is said when he fired the first stone, he was on the top of Slíabh Sneactá. When he threw it he jumped and he was at the foot of the hill before the stone.



There was a very poor man one time, and he had one cow, and he depended on this cow to keep him living. The cow used to graze on a hill near a field of benweeds. One Halloweve night the man could not find the cow. When he was looking for the cow, he came to this field of benweeds. He knew there were faries in this field, so he was afraid to go into it. At last he made up his mind that he would go into the field. There was
(continues on next page)

4428007/4367633/4549389.title: Rí Éireann
4428007/4367633/4549389.text:
Rí Éireann.Lá dár éirigh Fionn Mac Cúil, agus chuaidh sé síos go an cladach, agus chonnaic sé ag teacht isteach air, an  currach ba dheise le fághail.Iomradh cead air. Cabhair dá réag air, is gan ann ach aon fear amháin.Shíl Fionn imtheacht air, ach cheap an fear é. Annsin d'fiafruigh Fionn de cá raibh sé ag dul, agus dubhairt sé go raibh sé ag iarraidh maighistir. "Is maith an rud sin," arsa Fionn "agus mise ag iarraidh buachaill. Annsin thug Fionn leis abhaile é agus iongbhuigh sé é mar buachaill aimsire. Déirigh an buachaill ar maidin
(continues on next page)

4428339/4397081/4552285.title: Plúr na gCailín nÓg
4428339/4397081/4552285.text:
(continued from previous page)
a tháinig chuig Gleannfhinne agus a thug grádh do Ghráinne Ní Mhaoidhe a bhí in a comhnuidhe i Mín na Gualann fán am. Tá sí pósta anois ar Mháighistir Chéitinn. Chuidigh duine de na Maoidhigh le P.Ó Tiomanaidhe an dá dhán seo a dhéanamh.)



In blooming spring when warblers sing, and lambkins sport and playTo view this kind nature's charms I carefully did strayThrough Tirchonaill's glens and valleys my bicycle did spinTill I saw this fair enchanted spot that lies in fair Glenfinn.To describe these lovely sceneries and beauties most sublimeIt was my whole intention, in prose likewise in rhymeBut alas like one enchanted I dropped my feeble penWhen I met this gracious fair one whose smiles light up Glenfinn.It was cruel fate that tempted me those beauties to exploreI never thought that Cupid's dart woukd pierce me to the coreI was so free and happy I knew no guile or sinTill I met this charming fair one whose smiles light up Glenfinn.When I lie on my pillow to (gasp) in calm uposeIn dreams her form haunts me whenever my eyes do closeI think I hear the melodious voice in every sound and dinOf the kind and gracious fair one whose smiles light up Glenfinn.
(continues on next page)

4562126/4561724/4569130.title: Fionn Mac Cumhaill
4562126/4561724/4569130.text:
(continued from previous page)
agus nuair a bhí sin déanta aige chaith sé an lorg eile uaidh agus chuir sé in seasamh 'sa bhfairrge é. Léim sé air annsin agus annsin léim sé instach ar an taobh. Bhí trí lá thart sul a raibh caiple and airm thart ar an gCuan agus bhí Fionn imthigthe uathu.



Deirtear go na fianna amuigh agus bhfásach san Aifrcac fadó. Ag marbhughad ainmhidhtha bí siad. Marbhuigh sí an méid ainmhidhe nach raibh siad in-ann na sleaghanna a tabhtairt leo. D'fhág siad annsin iad agus d'imthigh siad abhaile. Seachtmhain ina-dhiaidh sin chuaidh Gall Mac Mórna, Caoilte agus Fionn go dtí an fásach leis an gléas arim a tabhairt abhaile leo acht fhad is a bhí siad siad sa mbhaile tháinig gaoth mór agus chuir sé cnoc (gairme) ós cionn na sleaghanna.  Bhí na fianna ag siubhal leo nuair a casadh fearín a bhí ar leath-chois leo. D'innis Fionn an scéal dó agus
(continues on next page)

4562122/4561355/4569313.title: Scéal Grinn
4562122/4561355/4569313.text:
Bhí fear agus a mhac ag dul go dtí an aonach lá. Bhí asal aca le díol. Chuaidh an mac ag marcuidheacht ar an asal. Casadh fear ortha, agus dubhairt sé leis an mac "nar mhór an náire dhuit bheith ag marcuidheacht ar an asal, agus d'athair bhocht ag siubhal." Tháinic an mach anuas de'n asal, agus chuaidh an athair ag marcuidheacht. Tar éis tamaill casadh fear eile ortha, agus dubhairt sé leis an athair "nár mhór an náire dhuit bheith ag marcuidheacht, agus do mhac bhocht ag siubhal." Dubhairt an athair leis an mac annsin teacht suas ar an asal leis. Tar éis tamaill casadh fear eile ortha, agus dubhairt sé leo "nár mhór an náire díobh bheith ag maruidheacht ar an asal bhocht, agus sibh féin indon siubhal níos fearr ná an asal bhocht. Ba cheart díobh an asal bhocht a iomchur. Tháiniceadar anuas d'en asal agus thosuigheadar gha iomchur. Tháinic na daoine amach as na tighthe ag gáire agus ag magadh fúta. Tháiniceadar go dtí droichead, agus thosuigh an asal ag léimniú, agus léim sé isteach san abhainn, agus báitheadh é. Bhí brón mór ar an bhfear.



Bhí a lán buachaill ag dul ins na Fianna lá. Bhí ortha dul treasna abha. Ní raibh aon caoi aca dul treasna ach é a léimniú. Léimeadar é. Nuair bhíodar ar
(continues on next page)

4562122/4561355/4569314.title: Scéal Grinn
4562122/4561355/4569314.text:

(continues on next page)

4562122/4561356/4569315.title: Seanscéal
4562122/4561356/4569315.text:
(continued from previous page)
an taobh eile chualadar guth ag rádh "tabhair congnamh dhom." D'fhéachadar isteach san abhainn, agus chonnaiceadar bean bhocht ag iarraidh teacht treasna na habhann. [?] D'imthigh na buachallaí go léir ach ceann aca. Chuaidh sé isteach san abhainn agus chuir sé an bhean suas ar a dhruim, agus thóg sé amach as an abhainn í. Bhí a chuid éaduigh salach annsin, agus cheap sé nach d'tiubhradh Fionn é ins na Fianna. Chuaidh sé go dtí na Fianna, agus thosuigh Fionn ag moladh é, mar gheall ar an ngníomh a rinne sé. Thug Fionn ins na Fianna é, ach níor thug sé na buacallaí eile.



Bhí a lán daoine ins na Fianna, agus bhí Fionn i gceannas ortha. Bhí mac ag Fionn darb ainm Oisín. Lá amháin bhíodar amuigh ag fiadhach, agus chonnaiceadar cailín aluinn ag teacht chuca ar capall bhán. Nuair tháinic sí go dtí iad tháinic sí anuas de'n chapall, agus chuir na Fianna na mílte fáilte róimpí. D'iarr Fionn uirrí cé'n ainm a bhí uirrí, agus cá raibh sí ag dul. Dubhairt sí gurbh í Niamh Cinn Óir a ainm, agus gur tháinic sí chun Oisín a thabhairt léi go Tír na nÓg. Annsin d'fhág Oisín slán dá athair agus do na Fianna eile. Chuaidh sé suas ar an gcapall leis an gcailín, agus as go bráth leo go Tír na nÓg. Ar a mbealach d'innis Niamh Cinn Óir le Oisín fá Tír na nÓg, agus nach d'tiocfadh aois ar aoine ann. Nuair shroiceadar an tír bhí iongnadh an domhain ar Oisín
(continues on next page)

4566079/4565222/4571821.title: Daoine Cáiliúla
4566079/4565222/4571821.text:
Deir na sean daoine go bhfuil na fir o menlo an laidír. Dubhairt na san daoine fadó freisin go raibh fir ón Chladaig an laidir. Bhí féar in-a chómhnaidhe i Cno A Diollan fadó agus bhí sé inn ann rith go h-ann tapaidh. O'Ratallaig an tainm a bhí air. Chuaidh sé amach go dtí America agus bhí meas mór ag na daoine air. Bhí sé in ann rith feichid nua feichid cuige mile a rith sa lo.



Ba é Fionn Mac Cumhail an fear ba caileamhla bhí sé go maith ag rith i rásaí agus bhí sé go maith ag léimnigh.Do leimeadh sé suas níos airde na é féin léimeadh sé gleanta ins na sliabhribh agus léimeadh sé abha mhóra agus léimeadh sé go leor rudaí eile abhí an ard s-an aer agus as sin bhaneadh sé caileamhla.Bhí sé in ann rith freisin. Rithead sé go tapaidh agus ní dhéanadh sé aon torann agus ní briseadh sé caipiní dar
(continues on next page)

4566068/4564200/4572697.title: Fiannaíocht
4566068/4564200/4572697.text:
FiannuíochtSa chéad leathanach eile tá cuid mhaith bheársaí faoin cómhra(h) in teamhair idir.Conán i Gall i Fianna Laighean. Cé nach bhfuil ann ach bheársaideacht is fiú súndas a thabhairt dó de bhrigh go dtaisbeánann sé an meas mór a bhí ag Connachtaigh ar a bhFianna féin is nach ndearnadar dearmad thiar againn-ne iad a mholadh nuair a thaínic an Fiannuíocht isteach  úa Fausiún. Tá an meid a tá annso leipaisteach b'feidir ach bhí sé a 'dul i gcodanna ar  Seán Each, Baile Dóighte, Béal Cláirnuair a thug sé dom-sa é.O'n a athair Pádraich Each a chuala Sean é ach tá Pádhraic iGoll anois ag fiadhach ins an Bánta Neámhdha. b
(continues on next page)

4428136/4381118/4572964.title: (no title)
4428136/4381118/4572964.text:
(continued from previous page)
[-]



[-]



Long ago Fionn and another number of persons were together in a house. soon they spied a man with a horse. The man pulled a hundred pounds from his pocket. "The man who guesses this horse's age will be given a
(continues on next page)



One day Fionn was hunting in a big wood. It was a very warm day and they had been hunting a long time. It was not long till a big wolf jumped in front of him. He overtook it before he was gone half a field.
4428136/4381118/4572964.school_info: School: Tuar an Fhíona, Cluain Meala

4566083/4565579/4573058.title: Seanscéal
4566083/4565579/4573058.text:
Bhí Fionn mac Cumhaill agus na Fianna agus Oisín ag fiadhach lá i gCo Ciarraighe. Chonnaiceadar bean ag marcaidheacht ar chapall ag teacht faoi na ndéin agus bhí sí gléasta go breagh. Do labhair sí le h-Oisín agus dubhairt sí leis gur chuir a h-athair i n-a choinne í. Chuaidh Oisín ag marcaidheacht ar an gcapall bán agus d'imthigheadar leobhtha go Tír na n-Óg. Bhí saoghal breagh aige i dTír na n-Óg agus níor éirigh sé níos sine ná bhí sé an lá a d'imthigh sé. Nuair a bhí sé trí chéad bliadhan i dTír na n-Óg dubhairt sé le hinghin an ríogh go mba mhaith leis dhul go h-Éireann go bhfeiceadh sé a athair agus a cháirde. Níor mhaith leithe é leigint ann i dtosach ach tar éis sgaithimh leig sí dhó imtheacht acht dubhairt sí leis gan a chos a leagaint ar thalamh na h-Éireann nó dá ndéanadh go n-éireochadh sé an-sean.Annsin thug sí an capall dó agus thainic sé go h-Éirinn. Bhí iongantas mór air nuair a tháinic sí go h-Éirinn ar fheiceáil dó go raibh na coillte móra gearrtha anuas agus an talamh saothruighthe i n- áit. Na daoine a bhí ag obair ins na páirceannaibh  cheap sé go raibh siad an-bheag i gcomórtas leis na daoine a bhí ann le n-a shaoghal-se. Bhí sé ag imtheacht leis go dtainic sé go Blá Cliath agus chonnaic
(continues on next page)

4566083/4565598/4573112.title: (no title)
4566083/4565598/4573112.text:
Tá go leor scéalta ag bainnt le Fionn agus na Fianna. Nuair a bhí Fionn óg matbhuigheadh a athar agus ar fhaitchíos go marbhóchaidhe é féin cuireadh i bhfolach é ins na sléibhte. Annsin chuaidh sé ina chomhnuidhe le draoi. Chuala an draoi go raibh iasg draoidheachta i n-abhainn na Bóinne. La rug an draoi ar an iasg agus thug sé do fhionn é le na róstadh. Nuair a bhí sé dhá róstadh leag sé a ordóg ar an iasg agus dóigheadh an ordóg ina bhéal do bhlas sé an t-iasg agus bhí fhios aige ar chuile rud agus sin é an chaoi a bhfuair Fionn an teolas mór a bhí aige



Uair amháin bhí buachaill ag tabhairt aire do ghort coirce a raibh coirce curtha innti ar fhaitíos go ngoidfeadh na h-éanacha é. Lá amháin bhí an lá an-te agus bhí an buachaill an-tuirseach de bharr a chuid shaothair. An lá seo tháinig Naomh Ciarán chuige agus d'fhiafruigh sé dhe céard a bhí air. "Ó" ars an mbuachaill. "Tá mé an-tuirseach de bharr mo chuid shoaothair". "Ná bíodh faithchíos ar bith ort" ars an Naoimh. "Tabharfaidh mise coghnamh duit". Do bhailigh an Naomh na h-éanacha ar fad le chéile agus chur sé isteach sa sgioból iad. Cuaidh an buachaill a codhladh go ceann i bhfad agus nuair d'éirigh sé arís leig Naomh Ciarán
(continues on next page)

4569043/4566370/4574322.title: The Landlord
4569043/4566370/4574322.text:
(continued from previous page)
the landlords. During their reign Ireland and it's people suffered very much, but they bore it bravely to the end and now we have no landlords, or any such men and every improvement a man makes on his farm, it is for his own good.



Sean Sgéalta.Tá sgéal ag na daoine atá in a gconai gcomhnuidhe tart timcheall na h-áite seo faoi Choich Osgair. Deireann siad gur chaith Osgar cloch ó Chon mhaicne mara agus gur thuit an chloch san fhairrge in aice le tamhain. Is féidir an chloch sin a fheiceál fós agus tugtar cloch Ogair uirthí. Tá sgéal ag na daoine atá in a gcomhnuidhe thart timcheall na h-áite seo faoin chaoi a bhfuair Cúculainn a ainm. Deireann siad go bhfuair Conchubhar Mac Neasa agus sgata de laochraibh na Craobhruaidhe cuireadh go féasta ó Culann árd gabha illadh. Bhí Setanta le teacht in a ndiaidh go dtí an féasta. Bhí cú mór fíochmhar ag
(continues on next page)

4566085/4565899/4574557.title: Ceathrú Mhóin Uisce
4566085/4565899/4574557.text:
The name of a townland in the parish of Oranmore. Some 50 years ago the people cut turf on this bog but the turf was unfit for use - it would not burn. A strange feature of the parish is the fact that there is no turf to be had there. The people have to travel to Galway to buy their turf from those people who come to Galway from Connemara with carts of turf on market days.



There was a woman who lived in the village of Ballinageeha. It happened this day that she was in a hurry going to the market in the town of Loughrea with flannel. This night a big crowd came in to her house at about twelve o'clock and they started to spin it. When it was spun they warped it wove it, and thickened it, and then it was ready to go to the market in the morning. All the men left at three o' clock in the morning when the cock crew. The wman decided to tell the priest, so she did and he told her to spread it in three corners of the graveyard. But the woman did not. She decided to sell it at the market. She left this morning about three o'clock as she thought but it
(continues on next page)

4566085/4565900/4574559.title: (no title)
4566085/4565900/4574559.text:
(continued from previous page)
happened to be only twelve. She went along the road and she met a man at a corssroads. She asked him the time and he told her it was about twelve o'clock. He asked her would she go along with him to a fort to nurse a child and that he would leave her back again in the same place. He told her when she would go in not to wonder at anything she would see. When she went in he gave her the child and she nursed it. When the man went to leave her out on the road she asked him why the old man behind the door was crying and he told her that there was a cow to calf in a certain place next night. They were to take the cow and leave the old man in her place and then they would have plenty of milk for the child. Then he told her never to leave her own house again until the cock would crow. She made the road to Loughrea then sold her flannel and came home happy.



There was one a blacksmith who had a very beautiful daughter. Of man came to ask

Diarmuid and Gráine slept in Cregg hill in a hole bedded by flags and the place is called "Leabaidh Diarmuid" agus Gráine" It is said that anyone that lied in that bed with a sore back would be cured in the morning.
(continues on next page)



One day the king of England sent for Gobán Saor and his son to come and build a castle for him. They went and each day the king asked gobán if the castle was yet

4583281/4576221/4583735.title: Old Irish Tales
4583281/4576221/4583735.text:
There are lots of stories told about the Fenians of long ago.People tell them around the fire on long winter nights.The fenians were soldiers who lived in Ireland long ago. They lived on the flesh of wild-deer and other wild animals. Finn Mac Cumhail was the leader of the Fenians.Long ago he threw a big heavy stone twelve miles, from Mount Mary to Killopin which is outside Ahascragh.Fionn had a son called Oisin, and Oisin had a son called Oscar. Finn was a great poet. He was hunting in the woods of Killarney one fine day.He saw a lady coming towards him riding a white horse. He went with her to Tie na nOg and they got married.He came back one day, and she told him when leaving not to touch Irish soil. When he came to Ireland, he saw six men trying to lift a heavy stone. He told the men he could lift it with one hand.
(continues on next page)

4583297/4577472/4586207.title: A Story about Finn Mac Cumhaill
4583297/4577472/4586207.text: Once upon a time there lived a great hero named Finn Mac Cumal. He was noted for his wisdom and fame all over Ireland. Finn had a band of warriors called the Fianna. They used spend six months hunting and six more guarding the coast.On one occasion when they were hunting they camped near the edge of a l

4583298/4577543/4586288.title: Old Irish Tales
4583298/4577543/4586288.text: When Cumhal and the Fianna were hurling in Cahermore turlough in the Parish of Kinvara Co Galway, his wife had the little boy on the side lines watching the game. During the game the little fellow getting interested in the game rushed in and hit the ball, the shot was so accurate that Cumhal said "Cé hé and páisdín Fionn"? His mother rushed in for him and said "You have now got your name so he was called Finn."Diarmuid and Grainne's Bed is in Crannagh, Gort, Galway. Whey they were fleeing from Finn they are said to have put up these huge stones

4583299/4577620/4587031.title: Old Irish Tales
4583299/4577620/4587031.text:
The old Irish tale that I know is about Oisin. One day when Oisin was out hunting by the banks of Loch Lein with the Fianna they saw a beautiful lady coming towards them and she had a golden cloak on her and hair that shone like gold. The hair was drooping down on her back and it was wavey and curly. When she came up to them she said that she was the daughter of the king of Tír na Nóg and that she wanted Oisín son of Finn. Finn said that it was Oisin that was along with them and she asked him to go along with her to Tír na nóg. Finn didnt want his son to go but Oisin fell in love with Eva and Oisin jumped up on the white horse. behind Eva and they rode off to Tir na nóg. Finn was crying and he was lonesome when
(continues on next page)

4583289/4576814/4587058.title: Stories of Fianna
4583289/4576814/4587058.text: One day St. Patrick was chatting with Oisin and he told him that God was a wonderful and very strong man.Oisin answered if I saw my son Oscar and God wrestling and God to put my Son on the broad of his back and keep him there the I would say he is a strong man.

4583289/4576815/4587061.title: Fenian Tale
4583289/4576815/4587061.text: The only fenian tale told in this district is about two fenians that had a fight. They stood on two high hills and they pelted stones at each other. The names of these hills is Mara Gan Uair and Mount Mary there is five miles distance between them.The man that stood on Mount Mary fired one stone and it rested in Sheep Walk the second one rested in Carthys farm and the third one rested where his opponent stood. The track of five fingers are to be seen in one of the stones yet.

4583308/4578377/4587770.title: Leaba Dhiarmada agus Gráinne
4583308/4578377/4587770.text: Deirtear nuair a bhí Diarmuid agus Grainne ag ticheadh ó na Fianna gur tháinig siad treasna na h-Éireann agus gur cuir siad fútha i Chevt Chace. Tá Chevy Chace i nDoire Bhuidhe i bParóiste Tobar Pheadair i nDeisceart, Conndao na Gaillimhe. Tá áit i lár na coille annsin agus tugtar "leabadh Diarmuda agus Gráinne air. Deirtear gur fhan siad annseo ar feadh i bhfad agus garaibh troid idir Diarmuid agus torc ann agus gur mharnhuigh an torc Diarmuid. Tháinig Gráinne slán ón torc agus d'imtigh sí o dhead go dtí loch Gráinne. Thuir sí isteach i dtobar annsin agus do scaip an uisge amach agus rinne sé Loch Gráinne. Bin deire saoghal Gráinne.

4583291/4576970/4591115.title: Scéal
4583291/4576970/4591115.text:

4583306/4578235/4592381.title: St Patrick's Track
4583306/4578235/4592381.text:
There is a stone in John Reilly's field Dereen Gort. It is said St. Patrick sat there. His track is there. It is called St. Patrick's Track.



In William Casey's field   in Derralifina, Gort there is a place called Leabaidh Diarmuid where three big stones stand erect and another placed in the top. Diarmuid brought two of
(continues on next page)

4583294/4577135/4592509.title: Rocks from Sliabh Muire
4583294/4577135/4592509.text:
390Rocks from Sliabh MuireFrom the ice age to the time of the Fianna there were three huge rocks on the summit of Sliabh Muire. One is still there towering above the whins and heather. Another is in the village of Curragh just across the Galway-Roscommon border, and the third is just visible above the waters of the River Suck, about thirty yards west of Athleague bridgeThe separation of those three rocks came about in this way. One day when Fionn Mac Cumhail and his companions were hunting on Sliabh Muire they
(continues on next page)

4591097/4590659/4592978.title: Folklore - Rocks from Sliabh Muire
4591097/4590659/4592978.text:
From the ice age to the time of the Fianna, there were three huge rocks on the summit of Sliabh Muire. One is still there towering above the whins and heather.  Another is in the village of Curragh just across the Galway-Roscommon border and the other is just visible above the water of the River Suck about thirty yards west of Athleague bridge. The separation of these three rocks came about in this way.  One day when Fionn Mac Cumhail and his companions were hunting on Sliabh Muire they grew weary from the efforts of the chase and sat down to on the summit of the mountain. Having rested they decided to a meal and soon a large stag was roasting on a log fire of immense size.
(continues on next page)

4583350/4582051/4606252.title: Story about Diarmuid and Gráinne
4583350/4582051/4606252.text: Diarmuid and Gráina were once at a dance.  Diarmuid were one of the Fenians.  Grána was going to get married to Finn and Diarmuid stole her away from the dance unknown to Finn.  They came to County Galway and travelled on through the mountains until they came to two flat flags in Paddy Spains land in Ballinahil.  They were so tired after their journey that they slept on the stones.  The two stones are running up beside one another.  And the stones are now called Leaba Diarmuid and Grána.

4602699/4596357/4614993.title: Seanscéal
4602699/4596357/4614993.text:
Ins an tsean-aimsir bhí Fionn Mac Cúl agus cúpla dhuine eile de na Fianna ag seilg i gcoill mór. Annsin tháinig an oidhche orthab agus ní rabhadar indon a theacht abhaile Bhí an oidhche an-dubh agus b'féigean dóibh luighe siar acht nuair a theann sé amach san oidhche bhí sé roinnt geal agus thosuigheadar ag siubhal timcheall na coille agus níor bhfhada go bhfhacadar solas sgathamh beag uatha. Bhí ocras orthab agus rinneadar air nuair a tháinig siad go dtí an solas bhí bóthar beag ann agus bhí sean-fhear istigh ann nuair a tháinig siad isteach chuir an fear fáilte roimhe na Fianna agus ghlaoidh sé i na ainm fhéin ar chuile dhuine de na Fianna agus bhí an-iongantas orthabh faoi go raibh aithne aige orthab.
(continues on next page)

4602699/4596360/4615002.title: Seanscéal
4602699/4596360/4615002.text:
Acht sa deiridh leag an tuan é agus chuir Fionn an duine ba goire dó amach agus leagh an tuan é freisin. Bhí Fionn Mac Cúl gcur amach i ndiaidh a chéile acht ní raibh aon duine dá ndeacha amach ná'r leag an t-uan nuair a bhí chuile duine de na Fianna leagthe aige an uan chuaidh Fionn amach agus bhí cor idir é fhéin agus an tuan agus leag an tuan é mar an gceana nuair a bhí cuile dhuine de na Fianna leagtha ag an uan chuaidh an sean fear é fhéin agus cheangeal sé an tuan agus bhí an-náire air na Fianna. Ná bíodh náire orthaibh arsa an sean-fhear is é an tuan sin an domhan seo agus níor bhfhéidir le aon duine é a leagan. Is sibh na fir is láidre san domhann seo (arsa ?) an sean-fear.
(continues on next page)

4602697/4596023/4615291.title: Scéal faoi na Fíníní
4602697/4596023/4615291.text:
Nuair a bhí na finíní ag imearc ag feadh tríd call fadó chonnaic siad teach beag. Tháinig siad go dtí an teach agus chuaigh siad isteach. Ní raibh isteach ach sean fear crion caint réabhrá roicigie cuir sé céad míle fáilte rompa suid siad síos ag caint. Bhí úan in ne leaba san gcluid dúirt sé agus chuaigh sé suad ar an bord dúirt Oisín Oscar goll mac móirne Diarmad na mban agus conán moal ó duine go duine ag iarraidh an chun a cuir anuas don b orm ainm sé ortha deirigh an sean fear ansin agus learg sé
(continues on next page)

4602687/4595234/4616559.title: Story
4602687/4595234/4616559.text:
A witch captured Finn Mac Cúl in a cave at the back of Túr and she told him that she would give him pardon if he would bring her Craithe na Gaise's head.  He started off travelling the mountains and he brought a lad with him. He was travelling for a long time when he met a little red man and a bow and arrow at him. He cocked the bow and arrow and shot Finn Mac Cú's companion. Finn said to him why did you shoot the only good friend I had. The little man said I'll be a better friend to you, you are a bad friend at first to do that. He asked Finn where was he going Finn was very slow in telling him. I know well said the little red man. Its as well for you to tell me go up on my shoulders. If I'll go up on your shoulders wouldint I bring you into the ground said Finn. See would you Finn went up on his shoulders, catch a good hold now said the little red man. The little red man gave a
(continues on next page)

4602684/4595142/4616640.title: Pisreoga
4602684/4595142/4616640.text:
1. Níl sé ceart luaithe an tighe a dhéanamh ar sean cosan. Mar bhéadh sé ar an mbealach ar na sidheóga.2. Níl sé ceart teach a dhéanamh ar sean cosán. Bhéadh sé ar an mbealach ar na sidheóga.3. Nuair a gheibheann capall nó bó bás ar duine gearann sé na cosa ó'n mbeithidheach ionnus nach bfeicfear ag siubhal arís é.



One Day Fionn was dining with "Conán Maol," A leg of beef and an oatmeal cake they had for the meal. "Conán "Maol" gave Fionn the leg of beef. Fionn ate it in a few bites and he asked if there was any more to eat. "Conán" said, "I thought you would have enough in one leg of beef." Fionn replied, "Indeed I often ate a blackbird which was better than your leg of beef." "Conán Maol " then cursed the blackbirds, and his curse caused them to be small and useless. Previous to that blackbirds were very large and people used to kill
(continues on next page)

4602684/4595142/4616642.title: Pisreoga
4602684/4595142/4616642.text:
1. Níl sé ceart luaithe an tighe a dhéanamh ar sean cosan. Mar bhéadh sé ar an mbealach ar na sidheóga.2. Níl sé ceart teach a dhéanamh ar sean cosán. Bhéadh sé ar an mbealach ar na sidheóga.3. Nuair a gheibheann capall nó bó bás ar duine gearann sé na cosa ó'n mbeithidheach ionnus nach bfeicfear ag siubhal arís é.



One Day Fionn was dining with "Conán Maol," A leg of beef and an oatmeal cake they had for the meal. "Conán "Maol" gave Fionn the leg of beef. Fionn ate it in a few bites and he asked if there was any more to eat. "Conán" said, "I thought you would have enough in one leg of beef." Fionn replied, "Indeed I often ate a blackbird which was better than your leg of beef." "Conán Maol " then cursed the blackbirds, and his curse caused them to be small and useless. Previous to that blackbirds were very large and people used to kill
(continues on next page)

4602684/4595143/4616643.title: A Story
4602684/4595143/4616643.text:
(continued from previous page)
and eat them.



Oisin was the son of Fionn Mac Cumhal and one of the Fianna. One day Oisin saw riding towards him a beautiful maiden mounted on a white steed. She came up to him and asked him to come with her toTir-na-n-og. She told him that Tir-na-n-og was a beautiful land where people never got old or never died. Oisin consented to go and the lady took him behind her on the steed. They rode through hills and valleys until they came to Tir-na-n-og. There they got married and had a wedding which lasted for seven days and seven nights. Oisin and Naoimh lived in a beautiful palace and were very happy. At last Oisin asked leave of Naoimh to go back to Ireland to see his friends. Naoimh gave him a white steed and told him if he dismounted the steed or touched green sod he would be changed into an old man, withered and grey and old.When Oisin came to Ireland he could see none
(continues on next page)

4613694/4609467/4625382.title: Story about Fionn
4613694/4609467/4625382.text:
One day Fionn came up to a lake and he saw a beautiful girl sitting on a stone on the shore. She looked very sad and Fionn asked her what was wrong with her. She said she had a beautiful ring with a shining purple stone and while she bathed in the late it slipped off her finger and sank to the bottom. Fionn took off his shos and his cloak and swam out in the lake to discover the ring. When he found it he handed it to the girl. She snatched it from him without thanking him and then she disappeared. When he came to the shore he found that he was a feeble old man and he had to sit down. He remained there for
(continues on next page)

4613694/4609468/4625383.title: (no title)
4613694/4609468/4625383.text: Deirtear go bhfuil cloch an mhór i dTeach Dóighte a bhain na Fianna as an talamh agus a d'fhág annsin í.Maighréád Breathnach,Teach Dóighte,Ros Cathail,Co. na Gaillimhe.

4613694/4609469/4625384.title: Story about Fionn
4613694/4609469/4625384.text:
(continued from previous page)
three days and he couldn't move. After that time his son Oisin came hunting and when he saw the old man he gave him alms. When Fionn spoke Oisin knew his voice and he brought him home on a stretcher of leaves. Then they brought him to the girl's father and they told him what had happened. He gave Fionn something to drink out of a glass and Fionn became as young as he had been before.



Bhí mada ag Fionn dárbh ainm dó Bran. Mada an maith a bhí ann. Bhí sé amuigh ag snámh lá agus báthadh é. Bhí briseadh croidhe ar Fhionn 'na dhiaidh.Brighidh Ní Chéide,Cluain Mór,Ros Cathail,Co. na Gaillimhe.

4613703/4610518/4625444.title: Seanscéal
4613703/4610518/4625444.text:
Sean sgéalChuaidh Goll, Conán, Diarmuid agus Oscair amach ag fiadhach lá. Chuadar achar fada as baile agus tháinig an oidhche ortha agus chuadar amugha. Chonnaiceadar solus uatha agus rinneadar air. Nuair a thainigeadar chomh fada leis an teach bhuaileadar ag an doras agus posgluigheadh lé sean-fhear é. Dubairt sé leob a dul isteach agus agus chuir sé ceád míle fáilte lé fianna na h-Éireann. Shuideadar síos agus leigeadar a sgíth. Tareís Tamaill Buail an sean fhear a dhá bois lé ceile agus tháinig beirt searbhóinte isteach. leagadar béile maith os comhair na bhfiann de chaoir fheoil muic feoil agus mairt fheoil agus fion agus dimthigheadar as amharc aríst. Annsin bhuail an
(continues on next page)

4613703/4610524/4625446.title: Scéal Fiannaíochta
4613703/4610524/4625446.text:
Nuair a bhí Naomh Pádhraic ag iarraidh Teampaill a dhéanamh, bhiodh rud eicínt ghá leagaint san oidhche agus ní raibh fhios aca beo céard a bhí ann. Acht nuair a tháinig Oisín ó Thír na n-Óg bhí sé dall agus dubhairt sé le Pádhraic dá dtugadh sé a amharc ar ais dhó go ndéanfadh sé fairiú air. Thosaigh Pádhraic ag guidhe agus fuair Oisín a amharc agus a neart ar ais. Thug sé claidheamh do agus d'fhan sé ag fairiú ar an dTeampaill annsin agus nuair a tháinig Pádhraic agus a chuid fear ar maidhin céard d'fheicfeadh siad acht oilphéist marbh agus an craicean iompuighthe  Oisín ina chodladh istigh ann agus a leath itthe aige agus dobh é an oilphéist sin a bhíodh ghá leagaint i gcomhnuidha san oidhche. Tháinig faitchíos ortha annsin dá gcuirfeadh siad fearg air go mabhochadh sé iad agus thosaigh Pádhraic ag guidhe arís agus baineadh an neart agus a amharc d'Oisín arís. Cuir siad a tarraingt cloch lé carr annsin é agus rinne sé an rann seo:-Mise Oisín indiaidh na FeinneAr mo dhruim ag tarraingt clochPer bith áit bhfuil mo ghreimIns an lín atá mo dheoch
(continues on next page)

4602689/4595356/4626079.title: Giantess
4602689/4595356/4626079.text: Once upon a time a man called Feicu, killed a giant.  One night Feica and Finn Mac Cool heard a great noise ocming near the house finn looked out the door, and the gianless was out side.  And she said finn man Cool O(tery usresc me) and he let her in, Fercu had a big souw hanging to the f roof and she asked him for a piece of the souw and he gave her some, and she made another grab and swallowed the whole lot.  She stood on the floor and asked feicu to fight her so he did and, She beat him.  finn Mac Cool caught her and but her to her knees in the floor and cut her head off.Ballinakill

4613698/4609882/4627855.title: Léim Diarmada
4613698/4609882/4627855.text: Nuair a bhí na "Fianna" ina gcomhnuidhe in Éirinn sa t-sean aimsir bhí gaisgidheach ann dar'bh ainm "Diarmuid".  Bhí sé indon chuile rud a dheanámh.  Lá amháin bhí sé féin is a bhean ag argoint agus sa deire dubhairt "Diarmuid" go léimfadh sé an charraig mhór a bhí in aice a theach.  Thug se an léim agus d'iarr a bhean dhó an léim a thógail ar as arís.  Thug sé é acht do theip air.  Thuith sé siar agus bhris sé a dhruim.  D'fhág sé a lorg ins an gcarraig.

4622966/4617943/4628372.title: Scéal Fiannaíochta
4622966/4617943/4628372.text:
Bhí bean ann fadó a raibh Deirdre mar ainm uirri. 'Sí an bhean badh breaghtha ar domhan í. Bhí sí choin dearg le rós agus chomh dubh leis an bhfiach dubh agus chomh geal leis an Sneachta Dubhairt sí nach bpósfadh sí aon fear choidhche acht fear a bheadh geal, dubh agus dearg. Bhí triúr deirbhrathaireacha in Albain, Naoise Mac Uisnigh, Árdán Mac Uisnigh, Ainnle Mac Uisnigh. Chuir sí fios anonn ortha agus tháinig siad go h-Éirinn. Phós sí Naoise mar badh é an fear badh shine aca é. Rí abheadh a hathair agus níos mhaith leis í dá pósadh agus bhí sé ag iarraidh íad a chur chun báis mar siad na triúr fir a b'fhearr 'sa domhan iad. Bhí cailleach draoidheachta thíos ina an urlár ag an Tigh agus bhí sé ag fághail chuile fhios uaithe. Chuir an Rí fios ar fathach go Sasana go marbhóchadh sé iad. Cuireadh chun troda é féin agus
(continues on next page)

metadata.Teacher:: Bríd Puirséal, Máire, Bean Uí Dhuibheagáin

4602726/4598680/4628460.title: How Ballintrillick Got its Name
4602726/4598680/4628460.text: The word Ballintrillick means "the way of the three stones." In the townland of Shancruck there are three large stones. These were thrown down the mountain by Fionn Mac Cool long ago and it is from these it derives its name.Not far from where these stones are situated there is a large cave in a mountain. It is said that a man named Diarmuid lived here for some time until he was killed by a wild boar.

4622977/4619704/4628726.title: (no title)
4622977/4619704/4628726.text:
Bhí fear ann fadó agus sé an t-ainm a bhí air Fionn. Bhí Fionn an-tsean agus ba mhaith leis bheith óg. Mar sin chuaidh sé ar fuaid na tire agus dubhairt sé len'a chuid saighdiúirí teacht leis go dtí Tír na nÓg. Chuadar leis agus bhíodar ag imtheacht leobhtha go dhtí gur casadh sean-fhear ar leath-thaoibh droichid dóibh.Nach bocht an áit í arsa Fionn gan teach amháin leis an oidhche a leigint thairn. Má thagann sibh liomsa tiubhraidh mé lóisdín na h-oidhche díbh, tá teach beag taobh thíos den droichid annseo agam. Cheap Fionn nach bhfeadfadh leath d'á cuid saighdiúirí dul isteach ins an teach beag seo, acht dá mbead oiread agus oiread eile ann d'féadfad siad dul isteach ann.Annsin d'fan Fionn agus a chuid saighdiúirí trí oidhche ins an dteach seo. An triomhadh oidhche d'fiafruigh an sean-fear de Fhionn cé an chaoi ar chaith sé an trí oidhche. “Bhail” arsa Fionn “an chéad oidhche nuair a bhí mé mo chodhladh tháinig bean maith go leór deas chugam isteach agus ní dhubhairt mé dadai léithe agus chuaidh sí amach arís. An dara oidhche tháinig bean áluinn deas isteach chugam agus shíl mé breith ortha agus chinn sé orm, agus an treas oidhche tháinig an bhean is grándha d'á bhfaca duine riamh agus níor bhac mé leithe agus d'imthigh sí (amach arís) leithe amach”. Annsin d'innis Fionn do'n sean-fhear cá raibh siad ag dul.“O” arsa an sean-fhear “tá sé chómh maith agaibh dul abhaile nuair nár rug tú ar an dara bhean. Dá mbeirthea ar an dara mnaoi bheadh an óige agat arís” An triomhadh oidhche nuair bhí siad ag ithe an suipéar bhí rotha ceangailti shuas i gceann an tighe agus bhris sé an ceangal a bhí air agus tháinig sé anuas agus sgeann sé an bord agus bhris sé cuid de na soithigh. Annsin dubhairt Fionn le ceann d'á cuid saighdiúirí eirigh agus
(continues on next page)

4622977/4619841/4629269.title: Fear na Stocaí
4622977/4619841/4629269.text:
(continued from previous page)
é agus sheas sé air agus thachtuigh sé é.  D’imthigh sé abhaile chómh tapaidh is bhí in a chosaí agus ní fhaca sé an gadhar ná an chailleach ó shoin i leith.2-XI-36Cuala mé an sgéal ó Mháirtín Ó Choidhin, Dubhlitir, An Fhairchi   Fear 50 blian. Ó na sean daoiní a chuala seisean é.S. mac an Riogh.

4622978/4619878/4629408.title: Searrach Óg
4622978/4619878/4629408.text:
(continued from previous page)

Fadó, nuair bhí Oisin i n-Éirinn, bhí ceithre clocha, mhóra, bhána taobh shiar de mo theach i gCnocáháin, dhá choic acú an-mhór, turaim is trí tonna meadhcaint, agus ní raibh an dá chloic eile comh mór, turaim is tonna go leith. Rug Oisin ar ceann de na clocaibh móra in a láimh dheis agus an cloch beag in a láimh dheis agus an cloch beag in a láimh clé agus caith sé iad dhá mile agus thuiteadar ar aghaidh tighe  - Máirtín Ó Seoige i nGleannglais agus tá siad ann ó shoin agus beidh go deo.

4622997/4622171/4630469.title: Old Irish Tales
4622997/4622171/4630469.text: It is said that the Fianna visited this parish when they came to Monaveen,Ballymacward, Woodlawn, Co. Galway. It is said that they a cave there and that they put an iron door to it. Móin na bhFiann means the 'Fianna's meadow'

4622986/4620951/4630753.title: An Dearg Mór
4622986/4620951/4630753.text:
An Dearg MórChuar an Dearg Mór, antaisgidheach as an Spáinn cuir sé cogadh ar na Fianna a bhí i n-Éirinn.Dudh in Goll, Fionn macCumhall, Oisín, Conán, agus Monán.Sgríobh Goll ar ais ag anDearg Mór go gcuirfeadh sé cogadhair agus a theacht go h-Éirinnagus godcroidhfeadh sé é.Tháinig an Dearg Mór agusnuair a tháinig sé chuir an Gollconán roimhe go bhfeicfeadh séchén cineál fir a bhí ann.tháinig conán ar ais agusdubhairt sé le Goll go marbhóchadhsé é. bhí sé chomh mór aguschomh láidir sin. Dfiafhraigh Goll dhá mháthair céard a déanfadh sé.Dubhairt sé leis 'A Ghoillluigh thusa isteach sa gcliabhánagus abróchaidh mise leis gurnaoidhnéán atá ann. Coinneóchaidhmise ag ól agus ag gaisgideaché go ceann trí lá.Rinne sé mar dubhairta máthair leis, tháinig an
(continues on next page)

4602750/4601012/4634793.title: Old Irish Tale
4602750/4601012/4634793.text: On Sliabh Tor mountain there is a cleft which is known as Leabaidh Ghráinne. In this place it is said Diarmiud and Grainne rested for one night in their flight from Fionn Mac Cumhaill. Before going to rest on the mountina Diarmiud and Grainne carried sand from the sea and brought it up to the mountain. On this they lay so when Fionn would put his finger to his wisdom tooth he would see them resting in the sand, therefore he would search the shores of Ireland for them. Then again it is told when Diarmuid and Grainne made their abode at the sea they lay on a bed of heather so when Fionn would apply his finger to the wisdom tooth he would see them on the mountain. Fionn would then spend some time in searching the mountain for them whereas they were at the sea. It is also told that the sand on which they lay is still to be seen on Tor mountain.

4605955/4605669/4644206.title: How the First Blackbird Come to Ireland
4605955/4605669/4644206.text: Michael Tiernan told me this.One time Finn Mac Cool was out in Norway and Finn had a great love for birds and the music of birds.He knew every bird's music and delighted himself listening to them.This day in Norway he heard the strange music and at once knew that no Irish bird could whistle so sweet. He had no peace or ease until he got the bird. It was a blackbird and he brought a pair to Allen in Co Kildare and kept them there. This pair lived on and became the parents of all the blackbirds we have.

4605956/4605815/4645119.title: Folklore
4605956/4605815/4645119.text: About a mile from here near Ballinboy there is a big stone on the side of the road which is supposed to be between four and five tons in weight.It is said that this stone was once on the top of Sheemore and that Fionn McCumhaill in a row threw it after another giant and the track of his hand is to be seen in it yet. He meant to throw it to the top of Sliab-an-Iarainn and it slipped off his hand when he was about to throw it.

4649686/4646928/4650111.title: The Giant
4649686/4646928/4650111.text:
The Giant."Long, long ago a great giant called MacHugh lived at Sheemore. He used to travel North, South, east and west, robbing the people and bringing home their cattle and their food to provide food for himself and his wife. One morning when he got up from bed he went down to the bottom of the hill and lifted a big rock from the bottom of the hill and flung it from him and it fell six miles away, and the place where it fell was ever afterwards called "Shee beig." There is a lough where he lifted the rock from. He used to step across to Scotland and rob and plunder there as well as at home. One day he took another giant's property in Scotland. The giant was angry
(continues on next page)
4649686/4646928/4650111.school_info: School: An Mhainistir, Cara Droma Ruisc

4649686/4646931/4650114.title: Sheemore
4649686/4646931/4650114.text:
"When Finn Mac Ceumh[?] used to go hunting round Ireland he sometimes would stop at Sheemore and spend the night in a cave there. One night he stayed there as usual and in the morning, he washed himself. He was so big and needed so much water, that when he threw it away it formed a little lake, which is still to be seen at the foot of Sheemore. In the old days there was a guest house on the side of Sheemore. Moran who owned it, kept a light burning all night to guide wayfarers in this lonely district. All who came were welcome and received refreshment. There is a story
(continues on next page)
4649686/4646931/4650114.school_info: School: An Mhainistir, Cara Droma Ruisc

4649691/4647714/4658914.title: (no title)
4649691/4647714/4658914.text:
The people say that Fionn Mac Cumhail had a great fight with Oscar the brave on Shee Beg. It was Fionn Mac Cumhail who won the battle and there was a cave near where the battle was fought. Fionn Mac Cumhail said "As it was at this cave I won the battle with Oscar I will make it my resting place anymore." So since that Diarmuid fought a battle with Fionn for Grainne on Shee Mór, Diarmuid won the battle.



Fionn Mac Cumhail was a very powerful man. One night as he was asleep in his cave he was awakened by robbers. He arose quickly and he killed two of the robbers. The rest had to fly for their lives.

4649691/4647714/4658919.title: (no title)
4649691/4647714/4658919.text:
The people say that Fionn Mac Cumhail had a great fight with Oscar the brave on Shee Beg. It was Fionn Mac Cumhail who won the battle and there was a cave near where the battle was fought. Fionn Mac Cumhail said "As it was at this cave I won the battle with Oscar I will make it my resting place anymore." So since that Diarmuid fought a battle with Fionn for Grainne on Shee Mór, Diarmuid won the battle.



Fionn Mac Cumhail was a very powerful man. One night as he was asleep in his cave he was awakened by robbers. He arose quickly and he killed two of the robbers. The rest had to fly for their lives.

4649691/4647715/4658925.title: (no title)
4649691/4647715/4658925.text: Paddy O'Leary who lived in Shebeg was a Fenian of the olden times. He did many brave deeds. He carried a gun with him. Himself and his comrades were very often pursued by soldier's. Many searches were made for his gun and fighting weapons which were not found until the day of his death he told his friend of his hiding place. It was in the pier of a gate. He was buried in a rath in Shanraw. There is a big flag stone at Charlie Carrol's house in the townland of Annaghkeenty which was thrown by Fionn Mac Cumhail from Shemore and it dropped on the top of Annakeenty hill. No man was able to lift it and it was broken in halves and one half was taken away but the other half is still to be seen.

4649691/4647716/4658930.title: (no title)
4649691/4647716/4658930.text: Fionn Mac Cumhail was a giant who lived in Shebeg. One day as he was out hunting he met a giant from Donegal who told Fionn Mac Cumhail that he would come to Shebeg on the following day and that they would have a fight. Fionn Mac Cumhail was terrified when he heard it because this giant was twice as tall as he was. When Fionn's wife saw the giant coming she put Fionn in the cradle. The giant came in and asked where was Fionn. The wife said he was out hunting. He saw Fionn in the cradle and he said "I see you have got a son" and he went and put his finger into Fionn's mouth to find out how many teeth and Fionn bit his finger. The giant said to the woman "If your (wife is) husband is anything like him he will do" and the giant went home and did not fight.

4658434/4655215/4659627.title: An Old Story
4658434/4655215/4659627.text:
One night as I was sitting at the fire an old man named Patrick Murray Keltyfea Cloone came in and I asked him to tell me a story and he told me this one.There was a Giant in Scotland one time and he had heard of Fionn MacCool and all the brave men he had defeated.  He made up his mind to come to Ireland and try to kill Fionn.  Fionn was looking out through the window and saw the Giant coming towards the house.  He was very much afraid of the Giant and he asked his wife what would be the best thing to do.  She told him to get into the cradle and that she would say that Fionn was away and that it was a son of Fionns that was in the cradle.  Fionn had just got into the cradle when the Giant came in on the door.  The Giant asked where Fionn was and the wife said that he had just gone out to hunt and he would not be back for a few days.  Shen then asked the Giant would be take some thing to eat and the Giant said he would.  She told him to go up to the hill and kill a cow.  The Giant went off to the hill to kill the cow where Oisin was
(continues on next page)

4613715/4611650/4659692.title: Rivers of North Kerry
4613715/4611650/4659692.text: Feale, Gale, Smearlagh, Brick and mouth of Feale or Cashen.1. The water of the Gale is lonesome water and black and boggy and no one goes bathing in it.2. About 300 yds. from the Square Listowel is a hole in Feale called "The Corporal's" or "The Corps". Here a Corporal of the British army was riding his horse across and was drowned. (8 people drowned here).3. "Big Bridge" Listowel built 1829. by (Simmonds?) Cork. Labourers got 10 d per day.4. Long 'go when the Danes (English?) were plundering the monasteries the monks at Lixnaw threw their silver bell into the River Brick and it's heard ringing still at certain times.5. One night a man went hunting down the "Furry Island" (Furgey Isl. near Listowel) and he couldn't come home till the cock crew, as every time he walked he was in the same place.6. They say the Fianna came up the Feale and played hurling "in a wide open space" which is the Island Race-[-] Listowel.7.

4591085/4589132/4661906.title: Grabaire Beag Fhinn Mhic Chumhaill
4591085/4589132/4661906.text:
Lá dá raibh Fionn ag siubhal amach casadh sean bhean dhó. D'fhiafruigh sí dhe an imróchadh sé cluiche cártaí. 'Níor thug mé mo chuid cártaí liom indiu', a deir Fionn. 'Níor fhág mise mo bhaile féin a deir an t-sean bhean gan mo phaca cártaí bheith ar iomchar agam'. Ní dhearna sí annsin ach stríoca a tharraingt ar an tráigh le cána a bhí in a láimh, agus rinne sí bord. Tharraing sí stríoca eile ag gach aon cheann dhe, agus rinne sí péire cathaoireacha. Chuir sí lámh in a póca agus tharraing sí aníos paca cártaí.Dubhairt sí le Fionn suidhe isteach nó go n-imireochaidís cluiche. Bhuaidh Fionn an chéad chluiche. 'Tabhair do bhreith a Fhinn', a deir an t-seanbhean. 'Beidh mé luath go leor, nuair a imireochas muis cluiche eile', d'fhreagair sé. Bhuaidh an t-sean bhean an darna cluiche. 'Cuirim-se de bhreith ort a deir sí gan stopadh ná cómhnaidhe a dhéanamh nó go dtuga tú chugam cloigeann Rí na Binne Bogaige'.'Cuirim-se de bhreith ort-sa a deir Fionn a dul ar stuaic an teampaill sin thall, punann tuighe a bheith ar bhinn de, pota uisge a bheith ar an mbinn eile, snáthad mór a bheith in do ghlaic, agus gan de bhiadh ná de dheoch a thabhairt nó go dtaga mise ar ais ach an méid a gheobhfas tú as an bpunann tuighe agus as an bpota uisge trí cró na snáthaide móire'. A! tóg diom an geasa, agus tógfaidh mise dhíot-sa é a deir an t-sean bhean. 'Deamhan a thógfad' a deir Fionn,
(continues on next page)

4591085/4589152/4662005.title: Conán Maol
4591085/4589152/4662005.text: Bhí fear ann fadó agus sé an t-ainm a bhí air Conán Maol. Duine de na Fianna do b'eadh é. Bhíodh sé i gcomhnaidhe ag eascainidhe agus bhaisteadar 'Conán Maol na Mallacht' air. Uair amháin bhí baintreabhach i mBlá Cliath agus ba chol-cheathar dhó í. Ba mhaith leis í a phósadh ach níor éirigh leis é sin do dhéanamh. Chuaidh sé ar bharr cnoc annsin agus ghlaoidh sé i mbarr a chinn 'tearaigh anuas anseo go bpósfaidh mé thú'.Níor chuala aon duine é agus d'imthigh sé do'n cnoc. Nuair a bhí sé ag tigheacht tríd na sléibhte chonnaic sé capall agus searach. Chuaidh sé ag marcaidheacht ar an gcapall agus casadh Fionn agus na Fianna dó, agus d'fhiafruigh siad de cá raibh sé agus sin a d'innis sé dóibh. Dubhairt Fionn leis 'Tearaigh anuas den chapall sin'. Annsin thosuigh sé ag eascainidhe agus thosuigh siad sin ag glaodhach Conán Maol na Mallacht air. Tháinig sé anuas de'n chapall annsin agus chuaidh sé in éinfheacht leis na Fianna. Chuaidh Conán agus na Fianna go dtí Sléibhte Chill Mhanntáin agus casadh an bhaintreabhach dóibh agus chuaidh Conán 'na diaidh agus d'fhiafruigh sé di an bpósadh sí é agus dubhairt sí nach bpósadh. Níor thaitnigh sé sin leis agus rith sé le'n anam go dtí na Fianna agus bhí an-bhriseadh croidhe air faoi nach bpósadh an bhean sin é. Dubhairt sé le Fionn bean deas uasal a fhághail dó agus dubhairt Fionn an bhfuil tú le scaradh uaim. Dubhairt Fionn go scaradh mar go gaithfeadh sé cailín deas a fhághail le h-aghaidh pósadh. Dubhairt sé le Fionn an bhaintreach a mhealladh go bpósfadh sé í agus dubhairt sé nach ndéanadh sé é. Deirtear gur cailleadh é le briseadh croidhe an oidhche sin nuair na bhfuigheadh sé an baintreach le pósadh.

4591085/4589155/4662047.title: Scéal - Conas mar Fuair Loch Deirg Dheirc A Ainm
4591085/4589155/4662047.text:
Fadó ariamh bhíodh na filí ag imtheacht ó thigh go tigh agus go mór mhór go tighthe na n-Ard Rí, agus d'iarraidís bístín dóibh féin i gcóir ha h-oidhche. Na rudaí a chloisidís na Rithe ag rádh ar feadh na h-oidhche dheinidís amhrán fútha ar maidin.Uair amháin do chuaidh file go dtí tigh an Ard-Rí ach bhí fhios ag an Rí céard a thug ann é, agus i gcaitheamh na h-oidhche d'éirigh troid eatorra. Rug an Rí ar an bhfile agus bhain sé súil as. Rith an file chun an tobair chun na súile do nígheadh. Le neart na fola bhí an t-uisge dearg. Dhein sé loch mór de'n tobar céadna agus ó shoin amach tugtar Loch Deirg Dheirc mar ainm ar an loch sin.



Fear ana láidir do beadh Goll Mac Mórna, agus bhíodh sé i gcómhnuidhe in éineacht le Oisín sul a ndeacha sé go Tír na n-Óg. Tar éis imtheacht d'Oisín bhíodh an-bhrón ar Gholl- tá sean fhocal againn  ' A Ghoill ná bíodh brón ort'. Duine de na Fianna do beadh é seo, agus bhíodh Fionn ag rádh leis i gcómhnaidhe gan bhrón a bheith air, go dtiocfadh Oisín
(continues on next page)

4591085/4589182/4662305.title: Diarmuid agus Gráinne
4591085/4589182/4662305.text:
Bhí beirt fhear i gCiarraighe Donn agus Siúrtán agus ní raibh aon bheirt fhear sa domhan ba mhó a raibh draoidheacht aca ná iad. Chuir Donn agus Siúrtán a mbeirt mhac go dtí draoidheadóir le foghluim, mar bhí an draoidheadóir seo an-láidir agus draoidheacht mór aige. Nuair a bhíodar sgathamh aige tháinig Fianna Éireann ar cuairt ins an teach a raibh an bheirt ghasúr ann agus bhí dinnéar mór ann, agus de réir mar bhíodar ag caitheamh an dinnéir bhíodar ag caitheadh na geamhanna amach ar an urlár chuig na cúnna. Nuair a bhí an dinnéar thart chuaidh chuile dhuine amach ach Donn, athair duine de na gasúir. Tháinig gasúr Shiúrtáin go dtí é agus chuir Donn idir a dhá ghlúin é agus d'fhág sé idir a lámha agus a ghlúine é gur mharbhuigh sé é. Chaith sé isteach é idir na cnámhanna san ait a raibh na gasúir ag piocadh na feola. Nuair a tháinig Siúrtán isteach bhí an-fhearg air nuair a chonnaic sé a mhac marbh.Annsin bhreathnuigh sé ins an chuile áit agus thóg sé suas é agus dubhairt sé nach iad na gadhair a mharbhuigh é. Thosaigh sé ag troid agus dubhairt sé gur duine éicint sa teach a mharbhuigh é. Bhí an argóint chomh mór go mb'éigean d'Fhionn a ordóg a chur ina bhéal ag dul dá cangailt féachaint an gadhar nó duine a mharbhuigh é. Fuair Fionn amach gurbh é Donn a mharbhuigh é agus dubhairt Fionn le Siúrtán sásamh a bhaint amach mar gheall a mhac a bhaith marbh. Dubhairt Siúrtán annsin nach dtiubhradh sé a mhc ar ór ná ar airgead ach an méid atá mé inann a dhéanamh déanfaidh mé é.
(continues on next page)

4666570/4662753/4666635.title: Fields
4666570/4662753/4666635.text: FieldsThe names of some of the fields in my townland are Lisheen Rúadh, the Fort field, and Léim na muiche. An important story is told about Léim ná Muiche.In the time of the Fianna when Diarmuid and Grania were fleeing from the anger of Fionn there is a tradition that they passed by this field. There is a chasm in the cliff side of the field and, when they reached the chasm they found they could not cross. They got on a pig's back, and suddenly the pig made a leap which took Diarmuid and Grania across to the other side of the chasm and ever since that time the field adjoining the chasm is called Léim na muiche. The field called the fort field got its name from the fort which is in it.                 Dan Daly 23 .6. 38  st.v                 Bromore, BallybunionMr. Dan Flahive, farmer, aged 72 Bromore, Ballybunion Co Kerry. (In whose land this field is.) got it from his own father.

4666600/4665637/4666645.title: Gleann na Léime
4666600/4665637/4666645.text: About three miles from the village is Gleann na Léime or the Glen of the Jump. Long ago people had a sportsfield in one of the highest hills near the stacks mountains. One day Fionn Mc Cumaill was out hunting and he was hungry [and?] tired and his clothes were torn. He was passing by the field and he saw a great crowd of people there. Fionn went in and looked at the [games] they were playing. He laughed when he saw them trying to throw weights and jump after [them]. As his clothes were torn the women laughed [him] to scorn. Fionn was so angry that he tore a rock out of the mountain and threw it two miles over the gleann and jumped after it. When he stood on top of the stone he jumped back to the field again. All the people were surprised [by?] this. The glen he jumped over is called Gleann na Léime. The stone is still to be seen in Glenballyma.

4666570/4662760/4666712.title: Local Historical Landmark
4666570/4662760/4666712.text: In a place near the cliffs three fields from our school there is a mound of earth which is locally called "Darby's Bed" Leaba Diarmada. It is said that Fionn expected Grania's hand in marriage but instead of she marrying Fionn she married Dermot. Dermot and Grania had to fly from the wrath of Fionn. They travelled round the cliffs  from Ballybunion and they crossed a chasm on a pig's back. This place is called Léim na muice as is stated before. On their travels they rested on a place only three fields from this school and ever since this lump of earth is locally called "Darby's Bed". We find on the  Sopers' and Miners' maps that the right name for this place is "Diarmuid and Grania's bed". This place is in the townland of Kilconly.

4666574/4663224/4666821.title: Cnoc an Áir
4666574/4663224/4666821.text: Cnoc an ÁirCnoc an Air means in English the "Hill of Slaughter".  It is situated North-East of Ballybunion.  This old legend is a fine one and very interesting.  This hill gets its name from a great battle which was fought there hundreds of years ago.  This is the story.One day Fionn Mac Cumhail and his men were hunting on this hill when they saw a beautiful lady coming towards them.  She told Fionn that she was pursued by (an - deleted) a man called Ceann Cair who was trying to force her to marry him.  She put Fionn under geasa to protect her.  It wasn't long until Ceann Cair landed with his boots on the ladies strand.  He entered a cave there with his warriors which is now called the Grand Cave.  This cave ended in a place called Moohane.When Ceann Cair left this cave he was met by Fionn and a terrible battle ensued.  There was so many killed on both sides that it was left to Oscar and Ceann Cair to decide the issue.  After a fierce battle Ceann Cair was slain by Oscar.

4666581/4663844/4667166.title: A Fenian Story
4666581/4663844/4667166.text:
FiannaA giant came from Limerick to Leathárdán in North Kerry. He came to a house and asked the woman of the house what were the men doing. She said they were minding bulls on the hill nearby. He asked her what exercise had they and she said throwing a stone that was seven tons over the castle. He said he would chance it and he threw the stone over the castle easily and caught it at the other side again. She was amazed at that. He asked her to serve him dinner. She gave him a
(continues on next page)

4666605/4666014/4667361.title: Historic
4666605/4666014/4667361.text: Bhiodh rásanna aige sna fianna ar an dtráigh fada atá idir Baile (Uí) Thaidhg & Fionáit. Do thosnuighidis ag baile (Uí) Thaidhg agus do bhiodh deire leo ag baile ana bheag cois farraige ar an dtaobh thiar thuaidh de Tráighlí ar a dtugtar Fionáit. Deirtear gur ó'n sgéul san a bhfuair sé an t'ainm.

4672098/4670289/4678461.title: A Fenian Tale
4672098/4670289/4678461.text:
John McHugh's grandfather worked for Major Hellas, Landlord [of] Dunacoye, Templeboy. The old man told John the following tale which happened while he was in Hellas' employment.At that time the railway from Dublin to the West was built only to Longford and people going to Dublin had to walk or drive to Longford.Old Johnny McHugh and most of the workmen in Hellas' {emplpyment] were in the Fenian movement and they had discovered that their password, "What are you up to Mike", was known to Hellas and probably to others outside the Fenian movement.Just at this time Hellas set out in his coach to Longford on his way to Dublin and the workmen believed that he was going specifically to reveal the password to the British authorities in the Castle.On his way to Longford he saw a man coming along the road. He ordered
(continues on next page)

4672109/4671029/4678506.title: Ossian in the Valley of the Black Pig
4672109/4671029/4678506.text:
It is said that Ossian lived many years after the death of the other Fianna untill the coming of St.Patrick who baptised him and made him a a Christian.It is also said that he spent the remainder of his days in the company of St.Patrick erecting churches and monasteries for him.Ossian was a giant compared with his companions and always ate the quarter of an ox for his dinner.One day he said he could get a larger black-bird that would have as much meat on her leg as was on the quarter of the ox.They said that they would give him a large reward if he would bring it to them.They also promised to give him
(continues on next page)

4678376/4673501/4678962.title: A Story
4678376/4673501/4678962.text:
Once upon a time there was a great big giant owned half the country. He was so bug that everybody who met him trembled with dread. At the same time Finn Mac Cual was a brave man and he lived in another part of the country and he was very fond of hunting. At last the giant heard of Finn. So he sent word to Finn he wished to know which of them was the strongest. When Finn received the word he was very troubled as he knew he was no match for the giant. Finn's wife being a very clever woman thought of a plan immediately and said she would help him. She had a sister living on the side of a mountain and whenever she wanted any thing she had only to wish three times. Now Finn's wife went to her one day and told her to procure all the cards she could find. Now Finn's wife went home and
(continues on next page)

4678386/4674833/4682172.title: Scéal ar Fhionn Mac Cumhaill
4678386/4674833/4682172.text:
Fadó do b'é Fionn a bhí 'na Árd rí ar Éirinn agus is air a bhí Éire a chosaint.  Bhí duine uasal láidir timcheall Loch Léin.  Bhí triúr fathach sa teorainn aige.  Bhídís ag guid agus ag fuadach gach oidhche uaidh.  Scríobhadh an duine uasal go dtí Fionn ag rádh leis teacht chuige.  Dhein Fionn suas é féin chun dul ag triall air mar bhí fhios aige gur gnó éigin fé leith a bhí ag an duine uasal so dho.  Chuaidh sé chuige agus thug sé leis a mhadra Bran agus a shleath.  Chuir an duine uasal na mílte fáilte roimis nuair a chuaidh sé chuige.  Níor innis sé dho an lá san in ao'chor cad é an cúram a bhí aige dho go dtí lár na mháireach.  Dubhairt sé leis ná raibh na fathaigh ag fágaint lí na lé aige.  Bhí san go maith is ní raibh go h-olc.  Nuair a bhí na buaibh crúidhte 'stoidhche lár na mháireach ag na cailíní freastail thiomáin an buachaill iad go dtí an ngort agus chuaidh Fionn le na chois. Cheangail sé Bran le trí
(continues on next page)

4678390/4675750/4682681.title: Na Triúr Fearaibh Gorma
4678390/4675750/4682681.text:
Aon lá amháin do bhí Fionn mach Cúmhail ag baint bháirneach ar thráig Fionn trágha agus chonnaic sé triúr feara ghorma ag gabháil isteach ón bhfairrge. Nuair a thánadar i naice lé Fionn dfhiafruighdear do Fhionn cá raibh na Fiadhna. Dúbhairt Fionn leótha go rabhadar ag fiach. I gceann tamaill dúbharadar lé Fionn ná báthad uisce iadh, agus ná dóghfad teine iad, & ná maróbhchadh claidheamh iad. Dúbhairt Fionn leó go dtrialladh sé féin ar dtúis sar a gcreidfheadh sé iad. Do fuair sé bloc mór adhmaid agus chuir sé ceann gach duine aca sínte ar. Do lámhsig sé a chlaidheamh agus bhuail gach duine aca acht do theip air. Deiríghdar aniar chómh maith is a bhí síad riamh. Annsan chuaid sé an choill agus bhailigh sé ghabhal bhrosna agus dhein teine dhóibh. Do bhuail sé an triúr isteach, agus an teine ar dearg lasadh. Bhíodar istig ar feadh ceathrú uair a chloig agus nuair a chonnaich Fíonn ná raibh an teine dá ndóghadh do thóg sé amach iad. Annsan thug sé fé an 3adh buadh a bhí aca féachaint an mbáthfhadh uisce iad.Do fuair sé naomhóg agus thug amach i lár an
(continues on next page)

4678402/4677496/4682698.title: An Corn sa Stór
4678402/4677496/4682698.text:
An Corn 'sa StórNuair a ghuid Rí na Gréige an Corn 'sa Stór ó Fionn Mac Cumhail, bhí fhios aige ná féadfadh aoinne é thabhairt thar nais dó acht Oscar. Dubhairt sé le Oscar iarracht a dhéanamh ar é thabhairt thar nais. Bhí ana leisce ar Oscar tabhairt fé, mar bhí fhios aige go gcaithfeadh sé troid chun san d'fhághail. D'imigh sé leis agus bhí órdughadh fachta aige ó Fionn cad a dhéanfadh sé nuair a sroisfeadh sé an fhairrge. Chaith sé scealpóg dá mhaide isteach sa pholl. Do dhein sé corachán aoibhinn áluinn aon chois do. Ní raibh páirt leata amach ná páirt leata isteach ach aon chleite amháin. Druimdhearg a bhí ar bharra an t-seoil mhóir ag déanamh ceoil. Bhí Lupadán Lapadán eisc mionna agus míolta móra ag teacht ar bhuis agus ar bhais i ngar barra na maidí Ráma ag éisteacht leis an corachán aoibhinn áluinn aon chois
(continues on next page)

4678402/4677500/4682703.title: An Gruagach agus Fionn
4678402/4677500/4682703.text:
An Grúgach agus FionnBhí bean ann fadó. Bhí beirt mhac aice agus cuplaí dhob' eadh iad. Ba mhór lei an trioblóid a bhí sí ag fághailt uatha. Lá amháin do buaileadh isteach i n-a h-aigne go mb'fhearra dí iad a bháthadh. Dhein sí dhá chiseán agus chuir sí leanbh isteach ins gach ceann. Leig sí síos leis an abhainn iad. Báthadh duine acu acht d'fhan an ciseán eile ag snámh ar bhárr an uisge. Bhí bean ag siúbhal ar bhruach na h-abhann tamall maith ó'n áit 'nar chaith sí isteach iad. Nuair a chonnaic sí an ciseán is an leanbh istigh ann tháinig iongnadh uirthe. Thug sí abhaile é agus d'fhás sé suas ar nós gach buachalla eile. B'é siúd an leanbh go dtugtar Fionn Mac Cumhail anois air. In-aois a seacht mbliadhan bhí sé ag eirghe ciallmhar. Cheap sé gurb í an bhean a thóg é a mháthair agus mar gheall ar sin bhí sé ceanamhail uirthi.Nuair a théigheadh sí go dtí an Baile Mór
(continues on next page)

4678399/4677058/4683126.text:

Sa dheire chuaidh sé isteach á lorg. Nuair a cuaidh sé isteach ní raibh an seirbhíseach ann in aon cor. Do glaoidh sé air acht ní bhfuair sé aon fhreagra. Taréis tamall d'eirig aníos as an dtalamh seacht lutharoga beaga. D'fiafhruig  sé dhóibh an bhfeacadar a sheirbhíseach féin. Dúbhradar go dtug a máighistir féin  leis é.  agus chuir sé iad féin  ina ionad. Dfiafhruig sé dhóibh annsan cár cómhnuigheadar. Dúbhairt duine aca gur cómhnuigheadar i dtír na bhfear gorm. Fuair Fíiónn Mac Cúmhail bád agus bhí sé á

4678382/4674129/4687763.title: An Fear Draíochta a Tháinig go dtís na Fianna
4678382/4674129/4687763.text:
Máire Ní Cheárna, An Bloscaod Mór, Dúnchaoin a thug an sceal so dhom. Tá sí inaois a cheithre fichid.Aon lá amháin bhí Fionn Mac Cúmhaill ag aoidhreacht ba thíos cois na trágha. Chonnaic sé chuige an fear agus é ag gabháil aniar tríd an bhfarraige, agus cliabh ar a dhrom aige. Gach breac a bhuaileadh leis chaitheadh sé isteach sa chléibh é le na órdóig. D'fiafruig se d'Fionn cá raibh tig na bhFiann. Theasbáin Fionn do é agus threóruig sé é ar an mbóthar. Ghaibh Fionn an cómhgar agus shrois sé an tig roimis. Chuaidh sé isteach sa chliabhán agus agus chuir sé an t-éadach 'na thímcheall.Tháinig an fear iasachta isteach agus bheannuig bean an tighe do, agus bheannuig sé di."Cá bhfuil na Fianna?" ar seisean."Táid as baile," ar sise."Cad é an t-aos atá an leanbh san sa chliabhán?" ars an fear."Tá sé trí bliadhna," ars an bhean.Chuir sé a ordóig siar 'na bhéal, agus níor dhein "an leanbh" ach luighe uirthi agus í a bhaint do."O Níl sí ró óg," ars an fear annsan."Cad a itheann na Fianna?" ars seisean.
(continues on next page)

4678400/4677275/4687894.title: Cath Fionntrá
4678400/4677275/4687894.text: Cath Fionn TrághaBí na Fianna tiar i bFionntrágha ag cosaint an bhádh í dtreó ná fhéadadh aon bhád teacht isteac. Aon oidhche amháin do tháinigh timcheall trí fichid bád isteach í ngan fhios do na Fianna.Do bhí fathach dhár ann fadó agus bhí sé 'na cómhnuidhe i gcaisleán, aon lá amháin do bhí troi ag Fionn agus an fathach. Bhíodar ag troid ar feadh lá agus oidhche agus an maidin na dhiaidh sin do mhairbh Fionn an fathach. On lá san amach d'féadfá dul treasna an abhainn gan do cosa do fhliuchadh. Is féidir fanacht ann go raghadh naoí tonnta amach annsan troineócadh an áit sin agus is féidir siúbhal treasna.

4687711/4686131/4688451.title: Eachtra na Mná Móire thar Lear
4687711/4686131/4688451.text:
Eachtra na Mná Móire Thar Lear.Aon lá amháin bhí Fionn Mac Cúmhail agus a chuid fórsaí ag fiadhach ar chnoc na bhFian. Do ghluais rómpa amach eilit mhaol agus do scaoil gach duine go léir a ghadhar féin 'na diaidh. Ba thapiula gadhar a bhí aige Fionn Mac Cumhail na seabhach ag imtheacht trí choill. Do scaoil Fionn féin a dhá ghadhar deag 'na diaidh agus beal baidhe. I gcúrsa an laé do lean na gadhair go léir í feag na laé go dtí an tráthnóna. Nuair a bhí drúcht agus deiriní agus meirinín ceoidh ag teacht do chuochadar cúcha na gadhair go léir trí chnocaibh, trí sléitibh go triseach trighin bruighte. D'fhíll go léir na gadhair go léir abhaile ach Bran. Do lean Bran í feag dhá lá agus dhá oidhche. Níor imthigh aon fiadhach riamh ó Bran ach an eilit mhaol. Do lean Bran í síos go dtí iochtar na hÍfreann agus do dhein sí bean dí féin ansan thíos in iochtar na hÍfreann, agus nuair a chnoc Bran gur dhein sí bean dí féinig d'fhill Bran a waile ansan. Bhí Fionn Mac Cumhail amuigh sa chnoch feachaint amach a nfheiceadh sé Bran cuige in aon chor. Chnoc se cuige Bran an tarna lá trí chnocaibh, trí sléitibh agus trí fíor bograchán; agus do luig sí 'ge cosaibh Fionn Mac Cumhail go tuirseach, tinn brúite tréis an dhá lá, agus do ghol go fuidheach. Sé dubhairt sí le Fionn Mac Cumhail "Is baolach liúm go gcuiridh sí an Fhéinn go léir chun báis. D'fhill an eilit mhaol an tarna lá, agus do tháinig sí i gclódh mná cúca." Fiosairím díot, a bhean mhaith, arsa Fionn Mac Cumhail, gud é
(continues on next page)
